   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Bulgaria
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>

     </a>

       This article is about the country. For other uses, see

       </a>
       .
      </div>

         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EU-Bulgaria.svg" title="Location of  Bulgaria  (dark green)– in Europe  (green &amp; dark grey)– in the European Union  (green)  –  [Legend]">

          <div style="text-align:center;font-size:11px;line-height:1.15em;">
           <span style="font-size:11px;">
            Location of

             </span>
            </span>
            (dark green)
           </span>

            – in
            <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
             Europe
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:8px;">
             <span class="nowrap">
             </span>
            </span>
            (green &amp; dark grey)
            <br/>
            – in the
            <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
             European Union
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:8px;">
             <span class="nowrap">
             </span>
            </span>
            (green)  –  [

      <p>
       <b>
        Bulgaria
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'b' in 'buy'">
            b
           </span>
           <span title="/ʌ/: 'u' in 'cut'">
            ʌ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="/ɡ/: 'g' in 'guy'">
            ɡ
           </span>
           <span title="/ɛər/: 'are' in 'bare'">
            ɛər
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
          </span>
          ,
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'b' in 'buy'">
            b
           </span>
           <span title="/ʊ/: 'oo' in 'foot'">
            ʊ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
          </span>
          -/
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Bulgaria.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c3/En-us-Bulgaria.ogg" title="En-us-Bulgaria.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">
        Bulgarian
       </a>
       :
       <span lang="bg">
        България
       </span>
       ,
       <small>
        <a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Bulgarian" title="Romanization of Bulgarian">
         tr.
        </a>
       </small>
       <i>
        Bǎlgariya
       </i>
       ), officially the
       <b>
        Republic of Bulgaria
       </b>
       (Bulgarian:
       <span lang="bg">
        Република България
       </span>
       ,
       <small>
        tr.
       </small>
       <i>
        Republika Bǎlgariya
       </i>
       ,
       <small>
        IPA:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Bulgarian_and_Macedonian" title="Help:IPA/Bulgarian and Macedonian">
         [rɛˈpublikɐ bɐɫˈɡarijɐ]
        </a>
       </span>
       ), is a country in
       <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">
        southeastern Europe
       </a>
       . It is bordered by
       <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
        Romania
       </a>
       to the north,
       <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
        Serbia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Macedonia" title="Republic of Macedonia">
        Macedonia
       </a>
       to the west,
       <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">
        Greece
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">
        Turkey
       </a>
       to the south, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">
        Black Sea
       </a>
       to the east. With a territory of 110,994 square kilometres (42,855 sq mi), Bulgaria is Europe's
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">
        16th-largest country
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Organised
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prehistoric" title="Prehistoric">
        prehistoric
       </a>
       cultures began developing on current Bulgarian lands during the
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        Neolithic
       </a>
       period. Its ancient history saw the presence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">
        Thracians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">
        Greeks
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">
        Persians
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">
        Celts
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Romans
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">
        Goths
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">
        Alans
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">
        Huns
       </a>
       . The emergence of a unified Bulgarian state dates back to the establishment of the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire" title="First Bulgarian Empire">
        First Bulgarian Empire
       </a>
       in 681 AD, which dominated most of the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
        Balkans
       </a>
       and functioned as a cultural hub for
       <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">
        Slavs
       </a>
       during the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       . With the downfall of the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire" title="Second Bulgarian Empire">
        Second Bulgarian Empire
       </a>
       in 1396, its territories came under
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">
        Ottoman
       </a>
       rule for nearly five centuries. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%9378)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–78)">
        Russo-Turkish War of 1877–78
       </a>
       led to the formation of the Third Bulgarian State. The following years saw several conflicts with its neighbours, which prompted Bulgaria to align with Germany in both world wars. In 1946 it became a one-party
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria" title="People's Republic of Bulgaria">
        socialist state
       </a>
       as part of the Soviet-led
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">
        Eastern Bloc
       </a>
       . In
       <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">
        December 1989
       </a>
       the ruling
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Communist_Party" title="Bulgarian Communist Party">
        Communist Party
       </a>
       allowed
       <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">
        multi-party
       </a>
       elections, which subsequently led to Bulgaria's transition into a
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
        democracy
       </a>
       and a market-based economy.
      </p>
      <p>
       Bulgaria's population of 7.2 million people is predominantly urbanised and mainly concentrated in the administrative centres of its
       <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Bulgaria" title="Provinces of Bulgaria">
        28 provinces
       </a>
       . Most commercial and cultural activities are centred on the capital and largest city,
       <a href="/wiki/Sofia" title="Sofia">
        Sofia
       </a>
       . The strongest sectors of the economy are heavy industry, power engineering, and agriculture, all of which rely on local natural resources.
      </p>
      <p>
       The country's current political structure dates to the adoption of a democratic constitution in 1991. Bulgaria is a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">
        parliamentary republic
       </a>
       with a high degree of political, administrative, and economic centralisation. It is a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">
        Council of Europe
       </a>
       ; a founding state of the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
        Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe
       </a>
       (OSCE); and has taken a seat at the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
        UN Security Council
       </a>
       three times.
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
        Etymology
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgars" title="Bulgars">
        Bulgars
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The country's name,
       <i>
        Bulgaria
       </i>
       is taken from the word,
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgars" title="Bulgars">
        Bulgars
       </a>
       , an extinct tribe of
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">
        Turkic
       </a>
       origin, which created the country. Within Bulgaria, some historians question the identification of the Bulgars as a Turkic tribe, in favor of their
       <a href="/wiki/Iranian_languages" title="Iranian languages">
        North Iranian
       </a>
       origin.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Their name is not completely understood and difficult to trace back earlier than the 4th century AD.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gurov_13-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gurov-13">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but it is possibly derived from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Turkic" title="Proto-Turkic">
        Proto-Turkic
       </a>
       word
       <i>
        bulģha
       </i>
       ("to mix", "shake", "stir") and its derivative
       <i>
        bulgak
       </i>
       ("revolt", "disorder")
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Alternate etymologies include derivation from a
       <a href="/wiki/Mongolic_languages" title="Mongolic languages">
        Mongolic
       </a>
       cognate
       <i>
        bulğarak
       </i>
       ("to separate", "split off")
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2011)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       or from a compound of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Turkic" title="Proto-Turkic">
        proto-Turkic
       </a>
       <i>
        bel
       </i>
       ("five") and
       <i>
        gur
       </i>
       ("arrow" in the sense of "
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_tribal_confederations" title="Turkic tribal confederations">
        tribe
       </a>
       "), a proposed division within the
       <a href="/wiki/Utigurs" title="Utigurs">
        Utigurs
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Onogurs" title="Onogurs">
        Onogurs
       </a>
       ("ten tribes").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria" title="History of Bulgaria">
        History of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks vcard" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%">
       <tr>
        <th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em">
         <div style="margin: -0.2em 0; font-size:65%; font-weight:normal;">
          Part of
          <a href="/wiki/Category:History_of_Bulgaria" title="Category:History of Bulgaria">
           <b>
            a series
           </b>
          </a>
          on the
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th class="vcard navbox-title" style="background: none; font-size: 145%;padding: 0.15em 0.1em;line-height: 1.2em;">
         <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria" title="History of Bulgaria">
          History of
          <span class="fn org label">
           Bulgaria
          </span>
         </a>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding: 0.2em; border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc;">
         <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">
          <img alt="Coat of arms of Bulgaria (version by constitution).svg" data-file-height="423" data-file-width="360" height="59" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Bulgaria_%28version_by_constitution%29.svg/50px-Coat_of_arms_of_Bulgaria_%28version_by_constitution%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Bulgaria_%28version_by_constitution%29.svg/75px-Coat_of_arms_of_Bulgaria_%28version_by_constitution%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Coat_of_arms_of_Bulgaria_%28version_by_constitution%29.svg/100px-Coat_of_arms_of_Bulgaria_%28version_by_constitution%29.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em;text-align:left; border-bottom:#aaa 1px solid;">
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">
            Odrysian kingdom
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            460 BC – 46 AD
           </span>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria#Roman_period" title="History of Bulgaria">
            Roman times
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            46–681
           </span>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria#Dark_Ages" title="History of Bulgaria">
            Dark Ages
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            6th–7th cent.
           </span>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire" title="First Bulgarian Empire">
            First Bulgarian Empire
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            681–1018
           </span>
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Bulgaria" title="Christianization of Bulgaria">
              Christianization
             </a>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Simeon_I_of_Bulgaria" title="Simeon I of Bulgaria">
              Golden Age
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              896–927
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Cometopuli_dynasty" title="Cometopuli dynasty">
              Cometopuli dynasty
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              968–1018
             </span>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria_(theme)" title="Bulgaria (theme)">
            Byzantine Bulgaria
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            1018–1185
           </span>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire" title="Second Bulgarian Empire">
            Second Bulgarian Empire
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            1185–1396
           </span>
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Asen_II_of_Bulgaria" title="Ivan Asen II of Bulgaria">
              Second Golden Age
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1230–1241
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Europe" title="Mongol invasion of Europe">
              Mongol invasion
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1274–1300
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Svetoslav_of_Bulgaria" title="Theodore Svetoslav of Bulgaria">
              Recovery and expansion
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1300–71
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian%E2%80%93Ottoman_wars" title="Bulgarian–Ottoman wars">
              Bulgarian–Ottoman wars
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1371–96
             </span>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Bulgaria" title="Ottoman Bulgaria">
            Ottoman Bulgaria
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            1396–1878
           </span>
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Hajduk#Bulgarian" title="Hajduk">
              Resistance
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              after 1413
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Revival" title="Bulgarian National Revival">
              National Revival
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1762–1878
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Exarchate" title="Bulgarian Exarchate">
              Establishment of the Bulgarian Exarchate
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1870
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)">
              Liberation War
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1877–1878
             </span>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria_(1878%E2%80%931946)" title="History of Bulgaria (1878–1946)">
            Third Bulgarian State
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            1878–present
           </span>
           <ul>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Serbo-Bulgarian_War" title="Serbo-Bulgarian War">
              Serbo-Bulgarian War
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1885
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">
              Balkan Wars
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1912–1913
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria_during_World_War_I" title="Bulgaria during World War I">
              World War I
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1915–1918
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bulgaria_during_World_War_II" title="Bulgaria during World War II">
              World War II
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1941–1945
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria" title="People's Republic of Bulgaria">
              Communist era
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              1946–1990
             </span>
            </li>
            <li>
             <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria_since_1989" title="History of Bulgaria since 1989">
              Transition era
             </a>
             <span style="color:#999">
              since 1990
             </span>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em;text-align:left; border-bottom:#aaa 1px solid;">
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/List_of_Bulgarian_monarchs" title="List of Bulgarian monarchs">
            List of monarchs
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Bulgaria" title="Military history of Bulgaria">
            Military history
           </a>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a href="/wiki/Internal_Macedonian_Revolutionary_Organization" title="Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization">
            Struggle for Macedonia
           </a>
           <span style="color:#999">
            1893–1945
           </span>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-bottom:#aaa 1px solid;">
         <a href="/wiki/Category:History_of_Bulgaria" title="Category:History of Bulgaria">
          Main category
         </a>
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg">
          <img alt="Flag of Bulgaria.svg" class="noviewer" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" height="10" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg/16px-Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg/24px-Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg/32px-Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Bulgaria" title="Portal:Bulgaria">
          Bulgaria portal
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%">
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_Bulgaria" title="Template:History of Bulgaria">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_Bulgaria" title="Template talk:History of Bulgaria">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_Bulgaria&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_antiquity">
        Prehistory and antiquity
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Europe" title="Neolithic Europe">
        Neolithic Europe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">
        Odrysian kingdom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">
        Thracians
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">
        Slavs
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Human activity in the lands of modern Bulgaria can be traced back to the
       <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">
        Paleolithic
       </a>
       . Organised prehistoric societies in Bulgarian lands include the
       <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
        Neolithic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Hamangia_culture" title="Hamangia culture">
        Hamangia culture
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_culture" title="Vinča culture">
        Vinča culture
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eneolithic" title="Eneolithic">
        eneolithic
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Varna_culture" title="Varna culture">
        Varna culture
       </a>
       (fifth millennium BC). The latter is credited with inventing
       <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">
        gold
       </a>
       working and exploitation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some of these first gold smelters produced the coins, weapons and jewellery of the
       <a href="/wiki/Varna_Necropolis" title="Varna Necropolis">
        Varna Necropolis treasure
       </a>
       , containing the oldest golden jewellery in the world with an approximate age of over 6,000 years.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This site also offers insights for understanding the social hierarchy of the earliest European societies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CENTCOM_22-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CENTCOM-22">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">
        Thracians
       </a>
       , one of the three primary ancestral groups of modern Bulgarians,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EBBulgars_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EBBulgars-23">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       began appearing in the region during the
       <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">
        Iron Age
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the late 6th century BC, the
       <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">
        Persians
       </a>
       conquered most of present-day Bulgaria.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_343–345_27-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_343–345-27">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and kept it until
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Persian_invasion_of_Greece" title="Second Persian invasion of Greece">
        479 BC
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_343–345_27-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_343–345-27">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With influence from the Persians,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington135–138,_343–345_28-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington135–138,_343–345-28">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the bulk of the Thracian tribes were united in the
       <a href="/wiki/Odrysian_kingdom" title="Odrysian kingdom">
        Odrysian kingdom
       </a>
       in the 470s BC by king
       <a href="/wiki/Teres_I" title="Teres I">
        Teres
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
        <a href="#cite_note-31">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but were later subjugated by
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">
        Alexander the Great
       </a>
       and by the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Romans
       </a>
       in 46 AD.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the division of the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Roman Empire
       </a>
       in the 5th century the area fell under
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine" title="Byzantine">
        Byzantine
       </a>
       control. By this time,
       <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
        Christianity
       </a>
       had already spread in the region. A small
       <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">
        Gothic
       </a>
       community in
       <a href="/wiki/Nicopolis_ad_Istrum" title="Nicopolis ad Istrum">
        Nicopolis ad Istrum
       </a>
       produced the first
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic language
       </a>
       book in the 4th century, the
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Bible" title="Gothic Bible">
        Wulfila Bible
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Monastery_of_Saint_Athanasius" title="Monastery of Saint Athanasius">
        first Christian monastery
       </a>
       in Europe was established around the same time by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Athanasius" title="Saint Athanasius">
        Saint Athanasius
       </a>
       in central Bulgaria.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From the 6th century the easternmost
       <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">
        South Slavs
       </a>
       gradually settled in the region, assimilating the partly Hellenised or Romanised Thracians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="First_Bulgarian_Empire">
        First Bulgarian Empire
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire" title="First Bulgarian Empire">
        First Bulgarian Empire
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Krum1.jpg">
         <img alt="Krum feasting with his nobles after the battle of Pliska, detail from the Manasses chronicle" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1296" data-file-width="1689" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Krum1.jpg/220px-Krum1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Krum1.jpg/330px-Krum1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Krum1.jpg/440px-Krum1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Krum1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Khan Krum feasts with his nobles after the battle of Pliska. His servant (far right) brings the wine-filled
         <a href="/wiki/Skull_cup" title="Skull cup">
          skull cup
         </a>
         of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nicephorus_I" title="Nicephorus I">
          Nicephorus I
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 680 the
       <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">
        Turkic
       </a>
       semi-nomadic
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgars" title="Bulgars">
        Bulgar
       </a>
       tribes
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EBBulgars_23-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EBBulgars-23">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       under the leadership of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asparukh_of_Bulgaria" title="Asparukh of Bulgaria">
        Asparukh
       </a>
       moved south across the
       <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">
        Danube
       </a>
       and settled in the area between the lower Danube and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Balkan" title="Balkan">
        Balkan
       </a>
       , establishing their capital at
       <a href="/wiki/Pliska" title="Pliska">
        Pliska
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A peace treaty with Byzantium in 681 marked the beginning of the
       <a href="/wiki/First_Bulgarian_Empire" title="First Bulgarian Empire">
        First Bulgarian Empire
       </a>
       . The Bulgars gradually mixed with the local population, adopting a common language on the basis of the local
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">
        Slavic
       </a>
       dialect.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Succeeding rulers strengthened the Bulgarian state throughout the 8th and 9th centuries.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Krum_of_Bulgaria" title="Krum of Bulgaria">
        Krum
       </a>
       doubled the country's territory, killed Byzantine emperor
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nicephorus_I" title="Nicephorus I">
        Nicephorus I
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Pliska" title="Battle of Pliska">
        Battle of Pliska
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and introduced the first written code of law. Paganism was abolished in favour of
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
        Eastern Orthodox Christianity
       </a>
       under
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_I_of_Bulgaria" title="Boris I of Bulgaria">
        Boris I
       </a>
       in 864. This
       <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Bulgaria" title="Christianization of Bulgaria">
        conversion
       </a>
       was followed by a Byzantine recognition of the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church" title="Bulgarian Orthodox Church">
        Bulgarian church
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the adoption of the
       <a href="/wiki/Cyrillic_script" title="Cyrillic script">
        Cyrillic alphabet
       </a>
       developed at
       <a href="/wiki/Preslav_Literary_School" title="Preslav Literary School">
        Preslav
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which strengthened central authority and helped fuse the Slavs and Bulgars into a unified people.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_44-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB-44">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RCJ_BG_45-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-RCJ_BG-45">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A subsequent cultural golden age began during the 34-year rule of
       <a href="/wiki/Simeon_I_of_Bulgaria" title="Simeon I of Bulgaria">
        Simeon the Great
       </a>
       , who also achieved the largest territorial expansion of the state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_First_Golden_Age_46-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_First_Golden_Age-46">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Wars with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Magyars" title="Magyars">
        Magyars
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pechenegs" title="Pechenegs">
        Pechenegs
       </a>
       and the spread of the
       <a href="/wiki/Bogomilism" title="Bogomilism">
        Bogomil heresy
       </a>
       weakened Bulgaria after Simeon's death.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Spread_47-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Spread-47">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Consecutive
       <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">
        Rus'
       </a>
       and Byzantine invasions resulted in the seizure of the capital
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Preslav" title="Preslav">
        Preslav
       </a>
       by the Byzantine army in 971.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under
       <a href="/wiki/Samuel_of_Bulgaria" title="Samuel of Bulgaria">
        Samuil
       </a>
       , Bulgaria briefly recovered from these attacks,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but this rise ended when Byzantine emperor
       <a href="/wiki/Basil_II" title="Basil II">
        Basil II
       </a>
       defeated the Bulgarian army at
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kleidion" title="Battle of Kleidion">
        Klyuch
       </a>
       in 1014. Samuil died shortly after the battle,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and by 1018 the Byzantines had ended the First Bulgarian Empire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Bulgarian_Empire">
        Second Bulgarian Empire
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire" title="Second Bulgarian Empire">
        Second Bulgarian Empire
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       After his conquest of Bulgaria,
       <a href="/wiki/Basil_II" title="Basil II">
        Basil II
       </a>
       prevented revolts and discontent by retaining the rule of the local nobility and by relieving the newly conquered lands of the obligation to pay taxes in gold, allowing them to be paid in kind instead.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ostrog_53-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ostrog-53">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He also allowed the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church" title="Bulgarian Orthodox Church">
        Bulgarian Patriarchate
       </a>
       to retain its
       <a href="/wiki/Autocephaly" title="Autocephaly">
        autocephalous status
       </a>
       and all its
       <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">
        dioceses
       </a>
       , but reduced it to an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orthodox_Archbishopric_of_Ohrid_(ancient)" title="Orthodox Archbishopric of Ohrid (ancient)">
        archbishopric
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ostrog_53-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ostrog-53">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After his death Byzantine domestic policies changed and a series of unsuccessful rebellions broke out,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bulgarian_uprising_against_the_Byzantine_Empire_(1040-1041)" title="Bulgarian uprising against the Byzantine Empire (1040-1041)">
        the largest
       </a>
       being led by
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Delyan" title="Peter Delyan">
        Peter Delyan
       </a>
       . In 1185
       <a href="/wiki/Asen_dynasty" title="Asen dynasty">
        Asen dynasty
       </a>
       nobles
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_Asen_I" title="Ivan Asen I">
        Ivan Asen I
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peter_IV_of_Bulgaria" title="Peter IV of Bulgaria">
        Peter IV
       </a>
       organised a
       <a href="/wiki/Uprising_of_Asen_and_Peter" title="Uprising of Asen and Peter">
        major uprising
       </a>
       which resulted in the re-establishment of the Bulgarian state. Ivan Asen and Peter laid the foundations of the Second Bulgarian Empire with
       <a href="/wiki/Veliko_Tarnovo" title="Veliko Tarnovo">
        Tarnovo
       </a>
       as the capital.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1821" data-file-width="3243" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg/220px-20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg/330px-20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg/440px-20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:20140621_Veliko_Tarnovo_002.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The walls of
         <a href="/wiki/Tsarevets_(fortress)" title="Tsarevets (fortress)">
          Tsarevets fortress
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Veliko_Tarnovo" title="Veliko Tarnovo">
          Veliko Tarnovo
         </a>
         , the capital of the second empire
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kaloyan" title="Kaloyan">
        Kaloyan
       </a>
       , the third of the Asen monarchs, extended his dominion to
       <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">
        Belgrade
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ohrid" title="Ohrid">
        Ohrid
       </a>
       . He acknowledged the spiritual supremacy of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_pope" title="The pope">
        the pope
       </a>
       and received a royal crown from a
       <a href="/wiki/Papal_legate" title="Papal legate">
        papal legate
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB1911_56-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB1911-56">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The empire reached its zenith under
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ivan_Asen_II" title="Ivan Asen II">
        Ivan Asen II
       </a>
       (1218–1241), when commerce and culture flourished.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB1911_56-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB1911-56">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The strong economic and religious influence of Tarnovo made it a "
       <a href="/wiki/Third_Rome" title="Third Rome">
        Third Rome
       </a>
       ", unlike the already declining Constantinople.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The country's military and economic might declined after the Asen dynasty ended in 1257, facing internal conflicts, constant Byzantine and Hungarian attacks and
       <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Europe" title="Mongol invasion of Europe">
        Mongol domination
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB1911_56-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB1911-56">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the end of the 14th century, factional divisions between
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boyars" title="Boyars">
        the feudal landlords
       </a>
       and the spread of Bogomilism had caused the Second Bulgarian Empire to split into three tsardoms—
       <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Vidin" title="Tsardom of Vidin">
        Vidin
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Bulgarian_Empire#Ivan_Alexander_and_fall_of_Bulgaria" title="Second Bulgarian Empire">
        Tarnovo
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_Dobruja" title="Despotate of Dobruja">
        Karvuna
       </a>
       —and several semi-independent principalities that fought each other, along with Byzantines, Hungarians, Serbs,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venetian_Republic" title="Venetian Republic">
        Venetians
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Genoese_Republic" title="Genoese Republic">
        Genoese
       </a>
       . By the late 14th century the
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turks" title="Ottoman Turks">
        Ottoman Turks
       </a>
       had started their conquest of Bulgaria and had taken most towns and fortresses south of the Balkan mountains.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB1911_56-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB1911-56">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_rule">
        Ottoman rule
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Bulgaria" title="Ottoman Bulgaria">
        Ottoman Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="676" data-file-width="482" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg/220px-Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg/330px-Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg/440px-Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hristo_Botev_by_Georgi_Danchov_Zografina.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Hristo_Botev" title="Hristo Botev">
          Hristo Botev
         </a>
         , a prominent revolutionary in the April Uprising
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Tarnovo was captured by the Ottomans after a three-month siege in 1393. After the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nicopolis" title="Battle of Nicopolis">
        Battle of Nicopolis
       </a>
       in 1396 brought about the fall of the Vidin Tsardom, the Ottomans conquered all Bulgarian lands south of the Danube. The nobility was eliminated and the peasantry was
       <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">
        enserfed
       </a>
       to Ottoman masters,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottoman_rule_59-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ottoman_rule-59">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with much of the educated clergy fleeing to other countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jireček_60-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jireček-60">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under the Ottoman system, Christians were considered an
       <a href="/wiki/Rayah" title="Rayah">
        inferior class
       </a>
       of people. Thus, Bulgarians, like other Christians, were subjected to heavy taxes and a small portion of the Bulgarian populace experienced partial or complete
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamisation" title="Islamisation">
        Islamisation
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and their culture was suppressed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jireček_60-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Jireček-60">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Ottoman authorities established the Rum
       <a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">
        Millet
       </a>
       , a religious administrative community which governed all Orthodox Christians regardless of their ethnicity.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Most of the local population gradually lost its distinct national consciousness, identifying as Christians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the clergy remaining in some isolated monasteries kept it alive, and that helped it to survive as in some rural, remote areas,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as in the militant
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Bulgaria" title="Roman Catholicism in Bulgaria">
        Catholic community
       </a>
       in the northwestern part of the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
        <a href="#cite_note-66">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Several Bulgarian revolts erupted throughout the nearly five centuries of Ottoman rule, most notably the
       <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">
        Habsburg
       </a>
       -backed
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Tarnovo uprisings
       <a href="/wiki/First_Tarnovo_Uprising" title="First Tarnovo Uprising">
        in 1598
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Tarnovo_Uprising" title="Second Tarnovo Uprising">
        in 1686
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiprovtsi_Uprising" title="Chiprovtsi Uprising">
        Chiprovtsi Uprising
       </a>
       in 1688 and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karposh%27s_Rebellion" title="Karposh's Rebellion">
        Karposh's Rebellion
       </a>
       in 1689.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottoman_rule_59-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ottoman_rule-59">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the 18th century, the
       <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">
        Enlightenment
       </a>
       in Western Europe provided influence for the initiation of a movement known as the
       <a href="/wiki/National_awakening_of_Bulgaria" title="National awakening of Bulgaria">
        National awakening of Bulgaria
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ottoman_rule_59-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ottoman_rule-59">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It restored national consciousness and became a key factor in the liberation struggle, resulting in the 1876
       <a href="/wiki/April_Uprising" title="April Uprising">
        April Uprising
       </a>
       . Up to 30,000 Bulgarians were killed as Ottoman authorities put down the rebellion. The massacres prompted the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Powers#History" title="Great Powers">
        Great Powers
       </a>
       to take action.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Final_Move_to_Independence_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Final_Move_to_Independence-68">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       They convened the
       <a href="/wiki/Constantinople_Conference" title="Constantinople Conference">
        Constantinople Conference
       </a>
       in 1876, but their decisions were rejected by the Ottomans. This allowed the
       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">
        Russian Empire
       </a>
       to seek a solution by force without risking military confrontation with other Great Powers, as had happened in the
       <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">
        Crimean War
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Final_Move_to_Independence_68-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Final_Move_to_Independence-68">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1877
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War,_1877%E2%80%931878" title="Russo-Turkish War, 1877–1878">
        Russia declared war
       </a>
       on the Ottoman Empire and defeated its forces with the help of
       <a href="/wiki/Opalchentsi" title="Opalchentsi">
        Bulgarian volunteers
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Third_Bulgarian_state">
        Third Bulgarian state
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria_(1878%E2%80%931946)" title="History of Bulgaria (1878–1946)">
        History of Bulgaria (1878–1946)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria" title="People's Republic of Bulgaria">
        People's Republic of Bulgaria
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Bulgaria_since_1989" title="History of Bulgaria since 1989">
        History of Bulgaria since 1989
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak,_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG">
         <img alt="The Defence of the Eagle's Nest, painting by Alexey Popov from 1893, depicting the Defence of Shipka Pass" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="827" data-file-width="1134" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak%2C_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG/220px-The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak%2C_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak%2C_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG/330px-The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak%2C_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak%2C_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG/440px-The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak%2C_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_defeat_of_Shipka_Peak,_Bulgarian_War_of_Independence.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Russian and Bulgarian
         <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Shipka_Pass" title="Battle of Shipka Pass">
          defence of Shipka Pass
         </a>
         was crucial for the independence of Bulgaria.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
          <a href="#cite_note-69">
           [67]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Stefano" title="Treaty of San Stefano">
        Treaty of San Stefano
       </a>
       was signed on 3 March 1878 by Russia and the Ottoman Empire, and included a provision to set up an autonomous Bulgarian principality roughly on the territories of the Second Bulgarian Empire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESan_Stefano,_Berlin_and_Independence_70-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESan_Stefano,_Berlin_and_Independence-70">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       3 March has since become
       <a href="/wiki/Liberation_Day" title="Liberation Day">
        Liberation Day
       </a>
       , a public holiday in Bulgaria,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       though the holiday was suppressed and fell out of favour following the left-wing uprising in 1944.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The other
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Powers#History" title="Great Powers">
        Great Powers
       </a>
       immediately rejected the treaty out of fear that such a large country in the Balkans might threaten their interests. It was superseded by the subsequent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Berlin,_1878" title="Treaty of Berlin, 1878">
        Treaty of Berlin
       </a>
       , signed on 13 July, which provided for a much smaller state comprising
       <a href="/wiki/Moesia" title="Moesia">
        Moesia
       </a>
       and the region of
       <a href="/wiki/Sofia" title="Sofia">
        Sofia
       </a>
       , leaving large populations of Bulgarians outside the new country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESan_Stefano,_Berlin_and_Independence_70-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESan_Stefano,_Berlin_and_Independence-70">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCProfile_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBCProfile-74">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This played a significant role in forming Bulgaria's militaristic approach to foreign affairs during the first half of the 20th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHistorical_Setting_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHistorical_Setting-75">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The Bulgarian principality won
       <a href="/wiki/Serbo-Bulgarian_War" title="Serbo-Bulgarian War">
        a war against Serbia
       </a>
       and incorporated the semi-autonomous Ottoman territory of
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Rumelia" title="Eastern Rumelia">
        Eastern Rumelia
       </a>
       in 1885, proclaiming itself an independent state on 5 October 1908.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the years following independence, Bulgaria increasingly militarised and was often referred to as "the Balkan
       <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">
        Prussia
       </a>
       ".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 1912 and 1918, Bulgaria became involved in three consecutive conflicts—two
       <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">
        Balkan Wars
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
        World War I
       </a>
       . After a disastrous defeat in the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">
        Second Balkan War
       </a>
       , Bulgaria again found itself fighting on the losing side as a result of its alliance with the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">
        Central Powers
       </a>
       in World War I. Despite fielding more than a quarter of its population in a 1,200,000-strong army
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and achieving several decisive victories, at
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Doiran_(1917)" title="Battle of Doiran (1917)">
        Doiran
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dobrich" title="Battle of Dobrich">
        Dobrich
       </a>
       , the country capitulated in 1918. The war resulted in significant territorial losses, and a total of 87,500 soldiers killed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than 253,000 refugees
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immigrated" title="Immigrated">
        immigrated
       </a>
       to Bulgaria from 1912 to 1929 due to the effects of these wars,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mintchev_1999_124_82-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Mintchev_1999_124-82">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       placing additional strain on the already ruined national economy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The political unrest resulting from these losses led to the establishment of a royal
       <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">
        authoritarian dictatorship
       </a>
       by Tsar
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_III_of_Bulgaria" title="Boris III of Bulgaria">
        Boris III
       </a>
       (1918–1943). Bulgaria entered World War II in 1941 as a member of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" title="Axis Powers">
        the Axis
       </a>
       but declined to participate in
       <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">
        Operation Barbarossa
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rescue_of_the_Bulgarian_Jews" title="Rescue of the Bulgarian Jews">
        saved its Jewish population
       </a>
       from deportation to
       <a href="/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camps" title="Nazi concentration camps">
        concentration camps
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBulgaria_in_World_War_II:_The_Passive_Alliance_84-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBulgaria_in_World_War_II:_The_Passive_Alliance-84">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The sudden death of Boris III in the summer of 1943 pushed the country into political turmoil as the war turned against Germany and the communist guerrilla movement gained momentum. The government of
       <a href="/wiki/Bogdan_Filov" title="Bogdan Filov">
        Bogdan Filov
       </a>
       subsequently failed to achieve peace with the Allies. Bulgaria did not comply with Soviet demands to expel German forces from its territory, resulting in a declaration of war and an invasion by the USSR in September 1944.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWartime_Crisis_85-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWartime_Crisis-85">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The communist-dominated
       <a href="/wiki/Fatherland_Front_(Bulgaria)" title="Fatherland Front (Bulgaria)">
        Fatherland Front
       </a>
       took power, ended participation in the Axis and joined the Allied side until the war ended.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_(contrasted).jpg">
         <img alt="Photograph of Bulgarian soldiers cutting enemy barbed wire during World War I: Bulgarian soldiers cutting barbed wire laid by the Entente Powers and preparing to advance." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="666" data-file-width="1024" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_%28contrasted%29.jpg/220px-Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_%28contrasted%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_%28contrasted%29.jpg/330px-Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_%28contrasted%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_%28contrasted%29.jpg/440px-Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_%28contrasted%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bulgarian_soldiers_with_wire_cutters_WWI_(contrasted).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bulgarian soldiers with wire cutters during WWI
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_of_1944" title="Bulgarian coup d'état of 1944">
        left-wing uprising
       </a>
       of 9 September 1944 led to the abolition of monarchic rule, but it was not until 1946 that a
       <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">
        one-party
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_republic" title="People's republic">
        people's republic
       </a>
       was established.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It became a part of the Soviet sphere of influence under the leadership of
       <a href="/wiki/Georgi_Dimitrov" title="Georgi Dimitrov">
        Georgi Dimitrov
       </a>
       (1946–1949), who laid the foundations for a rapidly industrialising
       <a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">
        Stalinist
       </a>
       state which was also highly repressive with thousands of dissidents executed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hanna_Arendt_Center_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Hanna_Arendt_Center-88">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the mid-1950s standards of living rose significantly,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDomestic_Policy_and_Its_Results_91-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDomestic_Policy_and_Its_Results-91">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while political repressions were lessened.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAfter_Stalin_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAfter_Stalin-92">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By the 1980s both national and per capita GDPs quadrupled,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but the economy remained prone to debt spikes, the most severe taking place in 1960, 1977 and 1980.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Soviet-style
       <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">
        planned economy
       </a>
       saw some market-oriented policies emerging on an experimental level under
       <a href="/wiki/Todor_Zhivkov" title="Todor Zhivkov">
        Todor Zhivkov
       </a>
       (1954–1989).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Economy_95-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Economy-95">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       His daughter
       <a href="/wiki/Lyudmila_Zhivkova" title="Lyudmila Zhivkova">
        Lyudmila
       </a>
       bolstered national pride by promoting Bulgarian heritage, culture and arts worldwide.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Political_Atmosphere_in_the_1970s_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Political_Atmosphere_in_the_1970s-96">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In an attempt to erase the identity of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turks_in_Bulgaria" title="Turks in Bulgaria">
        ethnic Turk
       </a>
       minority, an assimilation campaign was launched in 1984 which included closing mosques and forcing ethnic Turks to adopt Slavic names. These policies (combined with the end of communist rule in 1989) resulted in the emigration of some 300,000 ethnic Turks to Turkey.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Under the influence of the
       <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">
        collapsing of the Eastern Bloc
       </a>
       , on 10 November 1989 the Communist Party gave up its political monopoly, Zhivkov resigned, and Bulgaria embarked on a transition to a parliamentary democracy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_and_Politics_99-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_and_Politics-99">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first free elections in June 1990 were won by the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Socialist_Party" title="Bulgarian Socialist Party">
        Bulgarian Socialist Party
       </a>
       (BSP, the freshly renamed Communist Party).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Bulgaria" title="Constitution of Bulgaria">
        new constitution
       </a>
       that provided for a relatively weak elected president and for a prime minister accountable to the legislature was adopted in July 1991. The new system initially failed to improve living standards or create economic growth—the average quality of life and economic performance remained lower than under communism well into the early 2000s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A 1997 reform package restored economic growth, but living standards continued to suffer.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After 2001 economic, political and geopolitical conditions improved greatly,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616_103-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616-103">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and Bulgaria achieved high Human Development status.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It became a member of
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       in 2004
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nato_105-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nato-105">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and participated in the
       <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present)">
        War in Afghanistan
       </a>
       . After several years of reforms it joined the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       in 2007 despite continued concerns about government corruption.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VOA_106-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VOA-106">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
        Geography
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Bulgaria" title="Geography of Bulgaria">
        Geography of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg/330px-%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg/440px-%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%98%D0%B7%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4_%D0%BA%D1%8A%D0%BC_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0_%D0%BF%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Belogradchik_Rocks" title="Belogradchik Rocks">
          Belogradchik Rocks
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria occupies a portion of the eastern
       <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">
        Balkan
       </a>
       peninsula, bordering five countries—
       <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">
        Greece
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">
        Turkey
       </a>
       to the south,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macedonia_(country)" title="Macedonia (country)">
        Macedonia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">
        Serbia
       </a>
       to the west, and
       <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
        Romania
       </a>
       to the north. The land borders have a total length of 1,808 kilometres (1,123 mi), and the coastline has a length of 354 kilometres (220 mi).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064_107-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064-107">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Its total area of 110,994 square kilometres (42,855 sq mi) ranks it as the world's 105th-largest country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria's geographic coordinates are
       <a href="/wiki/43rd_parallel_north" title="43rd parallel north">
        43° N
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/25th_meridian_east" title="25th meridian east">
        25° E
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_110-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-110">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The most notable
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Topographical" title="Topographical">
        topographical
       </a>
       features are the
       <a href="/wiki/Danubian_Plain_(Bulgaria)" title="Danubian Plain (Bulgaria)">
        Danubian Plain
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Mountains" title="Balkan Mountains">
        Balkan Mountains
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thracian_Plain" title="Thracian Plain">
        Thracian Plain
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Rhodope_Mountains" title="Rhodope Mountains">
        Rhodope Mountains
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064_107-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064-107">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
