       The southern edge of the Danubian Plain slopes upward into the foothills of the Balkans, while the
       <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">
        Danube
       </a>
       defines the border with Romania. The
       <a href="/wiki/Thracia" title="Thracia">
        Thracian
       </a>
       Plain is roughly triangular, beginning southeast of
       <a href="/wiki/Sofia" title="Sofia">
        Sofia
       </a>
       and broadening as it reaches the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Black_Sea_Coast" title="Bulgarian Black Sea Coast">
        Black Sea coast
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064_107-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064-107">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner noresize" style="">
        <div class="thumbimage" style="">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg">
          <img alt="Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg/203px-Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg/305px-Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg/405px-Pirin-mountains-Bansko.jpg 2x" width="203"/>
         </a>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oilcape.jpg">
          <img alt="Oilcape.jpg" data-file-height="667" data-file-width="1000" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Oilcape.jpg/203px-Oilcape.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Oilcape.jpg/305px-Oilcape.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Oilcape.jpg/405px-Oilcape.jpg 2x" width="203"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         Left:
         <a href="/wiki/Pirin" title="Pirin">
          Pirin
         </a>
         Mountain in western Bulgaria
         <br/>
         Right:
         <i>
          Maslen nos
         </i>
         <a href="/wiki/Primorsko" title="Primorsko">
          Primorsko
         </a>
         on the Black Sea coast
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Balkan mountains run laterally through the middle of the country. The mountainous southwest of the country has two alpine ranges—
       <a href="/wiki/Rila" title="Rila">
        Rila
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pirin" title="Pirin">
        Pirin
       </a>
       , which border the lower but more extensive
       <a href="/wiki/Rhodope_Mountains" title="Rhodope Mountains">
        Rhodope Mountains
       </a>
       to the east.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064_107-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064-107">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is home to the highest point of the Balkan peninsula,
       <a href="/wiki/Musala" title="Musala">
        Musala
       </a>
       , at 2,925 metres (9,596 ft)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and its lowest point is sea level. Plains occupy about one-third of the territory, while plateaus and hills occupy 41 per cent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETopography_112-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETopography-112">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country has a dense network of about 540 rivers, most of which are relatively small and with low water levels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The longest river located solely in Bulgarian territory, the
       <a href="/wiki/Iskar_(river)" title="Iskar (river)">
        Iskar
       </a>
       , has a length of 368 kilometres (229 mi). Other major rivers include the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Struma_River" title="Struma River">
        Struma
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Maritsa" title="Maritsa">
        Maritsa
       </a>
       in the south.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064_107-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064-107">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Bulgaria has a dynamic climate, which results from its being positioned at the meeting point of
       <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">
        Mediterranean
       </a>
       and continental air masses and the barrier effect of its mountains.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064_107-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20064-107">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Northern Bulgaria averages 1 °C (1.8 °F) cooler and registers 200 millimetres (7.9 in) more precipitation annually than the regions south of the Balkan mountains. Temperature amplitudes vary significantly in different areas. The lowest recorded temperature is −38.3 °C (−36.9 °F), while the highest is 45.2 °C (113.4 °F).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">
        Precipitation
       </a>
       averages about 630 millimetres (24.8 in) per year, and varies from 500 millimetres (19.7 in) in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dobrudja" title="Dobrudja">
        Dobrudja
       </a>
       to more than 2,500 millimetres (98.4 in) in the mountains. Continental air masses bring significant amounts of snowfall during winter.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClimate_115-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClimate-115">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">
        Environment
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Bulgaria adopted the
       <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">
        Kyoto Protocol
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and achieved the protocol's objectives by reducing
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_emissions" title="Carbon dioxide emissions">
        carbon dioxide emissions
       </a>
       from 1990 to 2009 by 30 percent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, pollution from factories and metallurgy works and severe
       <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">
        deforestation
       </a>
       continue to cause major problems to the health and welfare of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013, air pollution in Bulgaria was more severe than any other European country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Urban areas are particularly affected by energy production from coal-based powerplants and automobile traffic,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while pesticide usage in the agriculture and antiquated industrial sewage systems produce extensive soil and water pollution with chemicals and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Detergents" title="Detergents">
        detergents
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ESI_122-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ESI-122">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is home to
       <a href="/wiki/Maritsa_Iztok_Complex" title="Maritsa Iztok Complex">
        Maritsa Iztok-2
       </a>
       , a
       <a href="/wiki/Lignite" title="Lignite">
        lignite
       </a>
       -fired power station causing the highest damage costs to
       <a href="/wiki/Health" title="Health">
        health
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Environmental_degradation" title="Environmental degradation">
        environment
       </a>
       in the entire European Union according to the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Environment_Agency" title="European Environment Agency">
        European Environment Agency
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EEA_123-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EEA-123">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is the only EU member which does not recycle municipal waste,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although an
       <a href="/wiki/Computer_recycling" title="Computer recycling">
        electronic waste recycling
       </a>
       plant opened in June 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The situation has improved in recent years, and several government-funded programs have been put into place in an attempt to reduce pollution levels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ESI_122-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ESI-122">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to Yale University's 2012
       <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">
        Environmental Performance Index
       </a>
       , Bulgaria is a "modest performer" in protecting the environment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Over 75% of surface rivers meet the standards for good quality. An improvement of water quality began in 1998 and has maintained a sustainable trend of moderate improvement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
        Biodiversity
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable selfref" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Category:Lists_of_biota_of_Bulgaria" title="Category:Lists of biota of Bulgaria">
        Category:Lists of biota of Bulgaria
       </a>
       .
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_fish_of_the_Black_Sea" title="List of fish of the Black Sea">
        List of fish of the Black Sea
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kamchiareserve.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="780" data-file-width="522" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Kamchiareserve.jpg/150px-Kamchiareserve.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Kamchiareserve.jpg/225px-Kamchiareserve.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Kamchiareserve.jpg/300px-Kamchiareserve.jpg 2x" width="150"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kamchiareserve.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Old-growth_forest" title="Old-growth forest">
          Alluvial forest (Longoz)
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Kamchia_(biosphere_reserve)" title="Kamchia (biosphere reserve)">
          Kamchia Biosphere Reserve
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The interaction of climatic, hydrological, geological and topographical conditions have produced a relatively wide variety of plant and animal species.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-biodiversity_128-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-biodiversity-128">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is one of the countries with highest
       <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">
        biodiversity
       </a>
       in Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-diversity_of_flora_and_fauna_129-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-diversity_of_flora_and_fauna-129">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria's biodiversity
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_protected_areas_of_Bulgaria" title="List of protected areas of Bulgaria">
        is conserved
       </a>
       in three national parks, 11 nature parks
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 16
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserve" title="Biosphere reserve">
        biosphere reserves
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nearly 35 per cent of its land area consists of forests,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       where some of the oldest trees in the world, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Baikushev%27s_pine" title="Baikushev's pine">
        Baikushev's pine
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Granit_oak" title="Granit oak">
        Granit oak
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       grow. Most of the plant and animal life is central European, although representatives of Arctic and alpine species are present at high altitudes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_Bio_134-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB_Bio-134">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Its flora encompass more than 3,800 species of which 170 are
       <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">
        endemic
       </a>
       and 150 are considered endangered.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A checklist of larger
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fungi" title="Fungi">
        fungi
       </a>
       of Bulgaria reported that more than 1,500 species occur in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Animal species include
       <a href="/wiki/Owl" title="Owl">
        owls
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rock_partridge" title="Rock partridge">
        rock partridges
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Wallcreeper" title="Wallcreeper">
        wallcreepers
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB_Bio_134-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EB_Bio-134">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">
        brown bears
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">
        Eurasian lynx
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_imperial_eagle" title="Eastern imperial eagle">
        eastern imperial eagle
       </a>
       have small, but growing populations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1998, the Bulgarian government approved the National Biological Diversity Conservation Strategy, a comprehensive programme seeking the preservation of local ecosystems, protection of endangered species and conservation of genetic resources.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria has some of the largest
       <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">
        Natura 2000
       </a>
       areas in Europe covering 33.8% of its territory.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Bulgaria" title="Politics of Bulgaria">
        Politics of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg">
         <img alt="The National Assembly building in Sofia" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="3298" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg/220px-National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg/330px-National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg/440px-National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Bulgaria.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The National Assembly building in
         <a href="/wiki/Sofia" title="Sofia">
          Sofia
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria is a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">
        parliamentary democracy
       </a>
       in which the most powerful executive position is that of prime minister.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616_103-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616-103">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The political system has three branches—legislative, executive and judicial, with
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">
        universal suffrage
       </a>
       for
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Citizen" title="Citizen">
        citizens
       </a>
       at least 18 years old. The
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Bulgaria" title="Constitution of Bulgaria">
        Constitution of Bulgaria
       </a>
       provides also possibilities of direct democracy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DD-Navi_141-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DD-Navi-141">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Elections are supervised by an independent Central Election Commission that includes members from all major political parties. Parties must register with the commission prior to participating in a national election.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200617_142-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200617-142">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Normally, the prime minister-elect is the leader of the party receiving the most votes in parliamentary elections, although this is not always the case.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616_103-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616-103">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Political parties gather in the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Bulgaria)" title="National Assembly (Bulgaria)">
        National Assembly
       </a>
       , which consists of 240 deputies elected to four-year terms by direct popular vote. The National Assembly has the power to enact laws, approve the budget, schedule presidential elections, select and dismiss the
       <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bulgaria" title="Prime Minister of Bulgaria">
        Prime Minister
       </a>
       and other ministers, declare war, deploy troops abroad, and ratify international treaties and agreements. The
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Bulgaria" title="President of Bulgaria">
        president
       </a>
       serves as the
       <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
        head of state
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">
        commander-in-chief
       </a>
       of the armed forces, and has the authority to return a bill for further debate, although the parliament can override the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidential_veto" title="Presidential veto">
        presidential veto
       </a>
       by a simple majority vote of all members of parliament.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616_103-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200616-103">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government">
        Government
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The first
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       government was formed after the centre right political party won the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_parliamentary_election,_2009" title="Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2009">
        2009 general election
       </a>
       in July with 117 seats in the National Assembly and ruling as a
       <a href="/wiki/Minority_government" title="Minority government">
        minority government
       </a>
       without support from the other political parties in the parliament.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, the government resigned on 20 February 2013 after
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protests_against_the_Borisov_cabinet" title="Protests against the Borisov cabinet">
        nationwide protests
       </a>
       caused by high costs of utilities, low living standards
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the failure of the democratic system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The protest wave was marked by self-immolations, spontaneous demonstrations and a strong sentiment against political parties.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
        <a href="#cite_note-146">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a consequence, the Parliament was dissolved and a new provisional government was set up by the President. The subsequent snap elections in
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_parliamentary_election,_2013" title="Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2013">
        May 2013
       </a>
       resulted in a narrow win for
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, with no support from the other three political parties that entered the parliament, on 24 May,
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       leader
       <a href="/wiki/Boyko_Borisov" title="Boyko Borisov">
        Boyko Borisov
       </a>
       returned the president's mandate to form a government. The
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Socialist_Party" title="Bulgarian Socialist Party">
        Bulgarian Socialist Party
       </a>
       nominated the ex-Finance Minister
       <a href="/wiki/Plamen_Oresharski" title="Plamen Oresharski">
        Plamen Oresharski
       </a>
       for the post of Prime Minister in May 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-form_148-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-form-148">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Only two weeks after its initial formation the Oresharski government came under opposition criticism and had to deal with another wave of
       <a href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_Bulgarian_protests_against_the_Oresharski_cabinet" title="2013–14 Bulgarian protests against the Oresharski cabinet">
        large-scale protests
       </a>
       some with more than 11 000 participants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government survived five
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vote_of_confidence" title="Vote of confidence">
        votes of no-confidence
       </a>
       before voluntarily resigning
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
       on 23 July 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On 6 August, a
       <a href="/wiki/Bliznashki_Government" title="Bliznashki Government">
        caretaker government
       </a>
       led by
       <a href="/wiki/Georgi_Bliznashki" title="Georgi Bliznashki">
        Georgi Bliznashki
       </a>
       was sworn into office and the Oresharski government was officially dissolved.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Protestsbg_17022013.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="396" data-file-width="640" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Protestsbg_17022013.jpg/220px-Protestsbg_17022013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Protestsbg_17022013.jpg/330px-Protestsbg_17022013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Protestsbg_17022013.jpg/440px-Protestsbg_17022013.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Protestsbg_17022013.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/2013_Bulgarian_protests_against_the_first_Borisov_cabinet" title="2013 Bulgarian protests against the first Borisov cabinet">
          2013 Bulgarian protests against the first Borisov cabinet
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       A new round of snap elections in
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_parliamentary_election,_2014" title="Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2014">
        October 2014
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sofia_News_Agency_154-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sofia_News_Agency-154">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       resulted in a third
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       victory with around a third of the vote. A record of eight parties won seats, the first time since the beginning of democratic elections in 1990 that more than seven parties entered parliament.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After being tasked by
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Bulgaria" title="List of heads of state of Bulgaria">
        President
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Rosen_Plevneliev" title="Rosen Plevneliev">
        Rosen Plevneliev
       </a>
       to form a government, Borisov's GERB
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Borisov_Government" title="Second Borisov Government">
        formed a coalition
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and members of the parties in the
       <a href="/wiki/Reformist_Bloc" title="Reformist Bloc">
        Reformist Bloc
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Democrats_for_a_Strong_Bulgaria" title="Democrats for a Strong Bulgaria">
        Democrats for a Strong Bulgaria (DSB)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Democratic_Forces_(Bulgaria)" title="Union of Democratic Forces (Bulgaria)">
        Union of Democratic Forces (SDS)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria_for_Citizens_Movement" title="Bulgaria for Citizens Movement">
        Bulgaria for Citizens Movement (DBG)
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Alternative_for_Bulgarian_Revival" title="Alternative for Bulgarian Revival">
        Alternative for Bulgarian Revival
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Agrarian_National_Union" title="Bulgarian Agrarian National Union">
        Bulgarian Agrarian National Union (BZNS)
       </a>
       ) were chosen for Minister positions. However,
       <a href="/wiki/Boyko_Borisov" title="Boyko Borisov">
        Boyko Borisov
       </a>
       made a vow in 2016 – should
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       President nominee
       <a href="/wiki/Tsetska_Tsacheva" title="Tsetska Tsacheva">
        Tsetska Tsacheva
       </a>
       does not win the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_presidential_election,_2016" title="Bulgarian presidential election, 2016">
        Bulgarian presidential election, 2016
       </a>
       , he would resign as a Prime Minister.
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       lost at this election from the independent candidate
       <a href="/wiki/Rumen_Radev" title="Rumen Radev">
        Rumen Radev
       </a>
       who was, nevertheless, supported by the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Socialist_Party" title="Bulgarian Socialist Party">
        Bulgarian Socialist Party
       </a>
       . Subsequently,
       <a href="/wiki/Boyko_Borisov" title="Boyko Borisov">
        Boyko Borisov
       </a>
       resigned for the second time. The new president
       <a href="/wiki/Rumen_Radev" title="Rumen Radev">
        Rumen Radev
       </a>
       formed a
       <a href="/wiki/Gerdzhikov_Government" title="Gerdzhikov Government">
        caretaker government
       </a>
       led by
       <a href="/wiki/Ognyan_Gerdzhikov" title="Ognyan Gerdzhikov">
        Ognyan Gerdzhikov
       </a>
       officially dissolving the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Borisov_Government" title="Second Borisov Government">
        Second Borisov Government
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       At the next snap elections in
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_parliamentary_election,_2017" title="Bulgarian parliamentary election, 2017">
        March 2017
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/GERB" title="GERB">
        GERB
       </a>
       won for the fourth time and four other parties entered the parliament –
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Socialist_Party" title="Bulgarian Socialist Party">
        Bulgarian Socialist Party
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Patriotic_Front_(Bulgaria)" title="Patriotic Front (Bulgaria)">
        Patriotic Front
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Movement_for_Rights_and_Freedoms" title="Movement for Rights and Freedoms">
        Movement for Rights and Freedoms
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Volia" title="Volia">
        Volia
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">
        Legal system
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Bulgaria has a typical
       <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">
        civil law
       </a>
       legal system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The judiciary is overseen by the Ministry of Justice. The Supreme Administrative Court and the Supreme Court of Cassation are the highest courts of appeal and oversee the application of laws in subordinate courts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200617_142-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200617-142">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Supreme Judicial Council manages the system and appoints judges. Bulgaria's judiciary, along with other institutions, remains one of Europe's most corrupt and inefficient.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Law enforcement is carried out by organisations mainly subordinate to the
       <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Bulgaria)" title="Ministry of Interior (Bulgaria)">
        Ministry of the Interior
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/National_Police_Service_(Bulgaria)" title="National Police Service (Bulgaria)">
        National Police Service
       </a>
       (NPS) combats general crime, maintains public order and supports the operations of other law enforcement agencies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       NPS fields 27,000 police officers in its local and national sections.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
        <a href="#cite_note-164">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Ministry of Interior also heads the Border Police Service and the
       <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie_(Bulgaria)" title="Gendarmerie (Bulgaria)">
        National Gendarmerie
       </a>
       —a specialised branch for anti-terrorist activity, crisis management and riot control. Counterintelligence and national security are the responsibility of the State Agency for National Security, established in 2008.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">
        Administrative divisions
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Bulgaria" title="Provinces of Bulgaria">
        Provinces of Bulgaria
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Bulgaria" title="Municipalities of Bulgaria">
        Municipalities of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria is a
       <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">
        unitary state
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since the 1880s, the number of territorial management units has varied from seven to 26.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Between 1987 and 1999 the administrative structure consisted of nine provinces (
       <i>
        oblasti
       </i>
       , singular
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Oblast" title="Oblast">
         oblast
        </a>
       </i>
       ). A new administrative structure was adopted in parallel with the decentralisation of the economic system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It includes 27 provinces and a metropolitan capital province (Sofia-Grad). All areas take their names from their respective capital cities. The provinces subdivide into 264
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Bulgaria" title="Municipalities of Bulgaria">
        municipalities
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Municipalities are run by mayors, who are elected to four-year terms, and by directly elected municipal councils. Bulgaria is a highly
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centralization" title="Centralization">
        centralised
       </a>
       state, where the national Council of Ministers directly appoints regional governors and all provinces and municipalities are heavily dependent on it for funding.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200617_142-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200617-142">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <center>
       <table cellpadding="10" style="margin:auto;">
        <tr>
         <td>
          <div class="floatright">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_Aministrative_Provinces_numbered.png">
            <img alt="Bulgaria Aministrative Provinces numbered.png" data-file-height="361" data-file-width="548" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Bulgaria_Aministrative_Provinces_numbered.png/300px-Bulgaria_Aministrative_Provinces_numbered.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Bulgaria_Aministrative_Provinces_numbered.png/450px-Bulgaria_Aministrative_Provinces_numbered.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/af/Bulgaria_Aministrative_Provinces_numbered.png 2x" width="300"/>
           </a>
          </div>
         </td>
         <td style="font-size:85%;font-weight:bold;">
          <div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-3" style="-moz-column-count: 3; -webkit-column-count: 3; column-count: 3;">
           <ol>

             </a>
            </li>

             </a>
            </li>
