            </li>
           </ol>
          </div>
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </center>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">
        Foreign relations
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bulgaria" title="Foreign relations of Bulgaria">
        Foreign relations of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG/220px-European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG/330px-European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG/440px-European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:European-parliament-brussels-inside.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The EU parliament in Brussels. Bulgaria is one of 28 member states of the European Union.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria became a member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       in 1955 and since 1966 has been a non-permanent member of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">
        Security Council
       </a>
       three times, most recently from 2002 to 2003.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria was also among the founding nations of the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">
        Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe
       </a>
       (OSCE) in 1975. It joined
       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">
        NATO
       </a>
       on 29 March 2004, signed the European Union
       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_2005" title="Treaty of Accession 2005">
        Treaty of Accession
       </a>
       on 25 April 2005,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nato_105-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-nato-105">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ec_170-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ec-170">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and became a full member of the European Union on 1 January 2007.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VOA_106-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-VOA-106">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Polls carried out seven years after the country's accession to the EU found only 15% of Bulgarians felt they had personally benefited from membership, with almost 40% of the population saying they would not bother to vote in the
       <a href="/wiki/Elections_to_the_European_Parliament" title="Elections to the European Parliament">
        2014 EU elections
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Euro-Atlantic integration became a priority for the country since the fall of Communism, although the Communist leadership also had aspirations of leaving the Warsaw Pact and joining the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">
        European Communities
       </a>
       by 1987.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [170]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
        <a href="#cite_note-174">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Bulgaria's relationship with its neighbours since 1990 has generally been good. The country also plays an important role in promoting regional security.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-State_175-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-State-175">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria has an active tripartite economic and diplomatic collaboration with Romania and Greece,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
        <a href="#cite_note-176">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       maintains strong relations with EU members, the United States, and Russia, and continues to improve its traditionally good ties with
       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
        China
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
        <a href="#cite_note-177">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">
        Vietnam
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
        <a href="#cite_note-178">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/HIV_trial_in_Libya" title="HIV trial in Libya">
        HIV trial in Libya
       </a>
       , which followed after the imprisonment of several Bulgarian nurses in
       <a href="/wiki/Benghazi" title="Benghazi">
        Benghazi
       </a>
       in 1998, had a significant impact on relations between Bulgaria, the European Union, and Libya. It resulted in the release of the nurses by Muammar Gaddafi's government, which was granted a contract to receive a nuclear reactor and weapons supplies from France in exchange.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
        <a href="#cite_note-179">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
        Military
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Bulgaria" title="Military of Bulgaria">
        Military of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png">
         <img alt="Bulgarian MiG-29 fighters in flight" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="760" data-file-width="1149" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png/220px-BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png/330px-BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png/440px-BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BAF_MiG-29s_in_flight_Garchev.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mikoyan_MiG-29" title="Mikoyan MiG-29">
          Mikoyan MiG-29
         </a>
         jet fighters of the
         <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Air_Force" title="Bulgarian Air Force">
          Bulgarian Air Force
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria hosted six
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KC-135_Stratotanker" title="KC-135 Stratotanker">
        KC-135 Stratotanker
       </a>
       aircraft and 200 support personnel for the war effort in Afghanistan in 2001, which was the first stationing of foreign forces on its territory since World War II.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CENTCOM_22-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-CENTCOM-22">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       International military relations were further expanded in April 2006, when Bulgaria and the United States signed a defence cooperation agreement providing for the usage of
       <a href="/wiki/Bezmer_Air_Base" title="Bezmer Air Base">
        Bezmer
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Graf_Ignatievo_Air_Base" title="Graf Ignatievo Air Base">
        Graf Ignatievo
       </a>
       air bases, the
       <a href="/wiki/Novo_Selo_Range" title="Novo Selo Range">
        Novo Selo
       </a>
       training range, and a logistics centre in
       <a href="/wiki/Aytos_Logistics_Center" title="Aytos Logistics Center">
        Aytos
       </a>
       as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_joint_US-Bulgarian_military_bases" title="List of joint US-Bulgarian military bases">
        joint military training facilities
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The same year
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_Policy_(magazine)" title="Foreign Policy (magazine)">
         Foreign Policy
        </a>
       </i>
       magazine listed Bezmer Air Base as one of the six most important overseas facilities used by the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">
        USAF
       </a>
       due to its proximity to the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">
        Middle East
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [179]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A total of 756 troops are
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Bulgaria#Deployments" title="Military of Bulgaria">
        deployed abroad
       </a>
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers">
          <span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (November 2016)">
           when?
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       as part of various UN and NATO missions. Historically, Bulgaria deployed significant numbers of military and civilian advisors in Soviet-allied countries, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Nicaraguan_Revolution" title="Nicaraguan Revolution">
        Nicaragua
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArms_Sales_182-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArms_Sales-182">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Socialist_People%27s_Libyan_Arab_Jamahiriya" title="Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya">
        Libya
       </a>
       (more than 9,000 personnel).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEForeign_Affairs_in_the_1960s_and_1970s_183-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEForeign_Affairs_in_the_1960s_and_1970s-183">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Domestic defence is the responsibility of the all-
       <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_military" title="Volunteer military">
        volunteer
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Bulgaria" title="Military of Bulgaria">
        military of Bulgaria
       </a>
       , consisting of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bulgarian_land_forces" title="Bulgarian land forces">
        land forces
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Navy" title="Bulgarian Navy">
        navy
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Air_Force" title="Bulgarian Air Force">
        air force
       </a>
       . The land forces consist of two mechanised brigades and eight independent regiments and battalions; the air force operates 106 aircraft and air defence systems in six air bases, and the navy operates a variety of ships, helicopters and coastal defence measures.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AF_plan_184-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-AF_plan-184">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following a series of reductions beginning in 1990, the number of active troops contracted from 152,000 in 1988
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMilitary_Personnel_185-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMilitary_Personnel-185">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       to about 32,000 in the 2000s,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
       supplemented in 2010 by a reserve force of 302,500 soldiers and officers and 34,000 paramilitary servicemen.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The inventory is mostly of Soviet origin, such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MiG-29" title="MiG-29">
        MiG-29
       </a>
       fighters,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SA-10_Grumble" title="SA-10 Grumble">
        SA-10 Grumble
       </a>
       SAMs and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SS-21_Scarab" title="SS-21 Scarab">
        SS-21 Scarab
       </a>
       short-range
       <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile" title="Ballistic missile">
        ballistic missiles
       </a>
       . As of 2012
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bulgaria&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the government planned to spend $1.4 billion
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
          <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (November 2016)">
           clarification needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       for the deployment of new fighter jets, communications systems and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyber_warfare" title="Cyber warfare">
        cyber warfare
       </a>
       capabilities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Total military spending for 2016 was BGN 1.3 billion (USD 560m).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Bulgaria" title="Economy of Bulgaria">
        Economy of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif">
         <img alt="Rates of economic growth (green and red) and unemployment (blue)" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="332" data-file-width="806" height="91" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif/220px-Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif/330px-Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif/440px-Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Economic_Growth_in_Bulgaria.gif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Rates of economic growth (green and red) and unemployment (blue)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria has an open
       <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">
        market economy
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in the upper middle income range,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       where the private sector accounts for more than 80% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       From a largely agricultural country with a predominantly rural population in 1948, by the 1980s Bulgaria had transformed into an industrial economy with scientific and technological research at the top of its budgetary expenditure priorities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The loss of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/COMECON" title="COMECON">
        COMECON
       </a>
       markets in 1990 and the subsequent "
       <a href="/wiki/Shock_therapy_(economics)" title="Shock therapy (economics)">
        shock therapy
       </a>
       " of the planned system caused a steep decline in industrial and agricultural production, ultimately followed by an economic collapse in 1997.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economies_194-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economies-194">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The economy largely recovered during a period of rapid growth several years later,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economies_194-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Economies-194">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but the average salary remains one of the lowest in the EU at 1,036 leva (€529) per month in March 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than a fifth of the labour force are employed on a
       <a href="/wiki/Minimum_wage" title="Minimum wage">
        minimum wage
       </a>
       of €1 per hour.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Wages, however, account for only half of the total household income,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       owing to the substantial
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Informal_economy" title="Informal economy">
        informal economy
       </a>
       which amounts to almost 32% of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgarian PPS
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP" title="GDP">
        GDP
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Per_capita" title="Per capita">
        per capita
       </a>
       stood at 47 per cent of the EU average in 2015 according to
       <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">
        Eurostat
       </a>
       data,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while at the same time the cost of living in the country was 47 per cent of the EU average as well.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The currency is the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_lev" title="Bulgarian lev">
        lev
       </a>
       , which is pegged to the euro at a rate of 1.95583 levа for 1 euro.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is not yet part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">
        eurozone
       </a>
       but is showing progress.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="686" data-file-width="2000" height="75" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg/220px-Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg/330px-Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg/440px-Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sunny-Beach-BDimitrov.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Sunny_Beach" title="Sunny Beach">
          Sunny Beach
         </a>
         on the
         <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Black_Sea_Coast" title="Bulgarian Black Sea Coast">
          Bulgarian Black Sea Coast
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Economic indicators have improved after the
       <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">
        financial crisis of 2007–2008
       </a>
       . After several consecutive years of high growth, GDP contracted 5.5 per cent in 2009 and unemployment remained above 12 per cent.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurostat_crisis_205-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_crisis-205">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Industrial output declined 10 per cent, mining by 31 per cent, and ferrous and metal production marked a 60 per cent drop.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Positive growth was restored in 2010,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurostat_crisis_205-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_crisis-205">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although investments and consumption continue to decline steadily due to rising unemployment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The same year, intercompany debt exceeded €51 billion, meaning that 60 per cent of all Bulgarian companies were mutually indebted.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By 2012, it had increased to €83 billion, or 227 per cent of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government implemented strict austerity measures with IMF and EU encouragement to some positive fiscal results, but the social consequences of these measures have been "catastrophic" according to the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Trade_Union_Confederation" title="International Trade Union Confederation">
        International Trade Union Confederation
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Corruption" title="Corruption">
        Corruption
       </a>
       remains another obstacle to economic growth. Bulgaria is one of the most corrupt European Union members and ranks 75th in the
       <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">
        Corruption Perceptions Index
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Weak law enforcement and overall low capacity of civil service remain as challenges in curbing corruption. However, fighting against corruption has become the focus of the government because of the EU accession, and several anti-corruption programs have been undertaken by different government agencies.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_export_partners.png">
         <img alt="Map showing Bulgaria and its main export partners by share of total exports" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1200" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Bulgaria_export_partners.png/220px-Bulgaria_export_partners.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Bulgaria_export_partners.png/330px-Bulgaria_export_partners.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Bulgaria_export_partners.png/440px-Bulgaria_export_partners.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_export_partners.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bulgaria (orange) and its largest export partners by share of total exports
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Economic activities are fostered by the lowest personal and corporate income tax rates in the EU,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the third-lowest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_debt" title="Public debt">
        public debt
       </a>
       of all member states at 28.7% of GDP in 2016.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016, GDP (
       <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">
        PPP
       </a>
       ) was estimated at $143.1 billion, with a per capita value of $20,116.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_215-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-imf2-215">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Sofia and the surrounding
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yugozapaden" title="Yugozapaden">
        Yugozapaden
       </a>
       planning area are the most developed region of the country with a per capita PPS GDP of €20,600 ($27,400) in 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is a net receiver of funds from the EU. The absolute amount of received funds was €589 million in 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The labour force is 2.45 million people,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of whom 7.1 per cent are employed in agriculture, 35.2 per cent are employed in industry and 57.7 per cent are employed in the services sector.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Extraction of metals and minerals, production of
       <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">
        chemicals
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Machinery_industry" title="Machinery industry">
        machinery
       </a>
       and vehicle components,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refined_petroleum_fuel" title="Refined petroleum fuel">
        petroleum refining
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and steel are among the major industrial activities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mining and its related industries employ a total of 120,000 people and generate about five per cent of the country's GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ore_exports_223-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ore_exports-223">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is Europe's sixth-largest coal producer.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ore_exports_223-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ore_exports-223">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Local deposits of coal, iron, copper and lead are vital for the manufacturing and energy sectors.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEResource_Base_225-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEResource_Base-225">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Almost all top export items of Bulgaria are industrial commodities such as oil products, copper products and pharmaceuticals.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNdata_226-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNdata-226">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria is also a net exporter of agricultural and food products, of which two-thirds go to
       <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
        OECD
       </a>
       countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is the largest global producer of perfumery essential oils such as
       <a href="/wiki/Lavender_oil" title="Lavender oil">
        lavender
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Rose_oil" title="Rose oil">
        rose oil
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CENTCOM_22-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-CENTCOM-22">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Agriculture has declined significantly in the past two decades. Production in 2008 amounted to only 66 per cent of that between 1999 and 2001,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNdata_226-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNdata-226">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while cereal and vegetable yields have dropped by nearly 40 per cent since 1990.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Of the services sector,
       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Bulgaria" title="Tourism in Bulgaria">
        tourism
       </a>
       is the most significant contributor to economic growth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-general_tourism_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-general_tourism-230">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In recent years, Bulgaria has emerged as a travelling destination with its inexpensive resorts and beaches outside the reach of the tourist industry.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Lonely_Planet" title="Lonely Planet">
        Lonely Planet
       </a>
       ranked it among its top 10 destinations for 2011.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Most of the visitors are British, Romanian, German and Russian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The capital
       <a href="/wiki/Sofia" title="Sofia">
        Sofia
       </a>
       , the medieval capital
       <a href="/wiki/Veliko_Tarnovo" title="Veliko Tarnovo">
        Veliko Tarnovo
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
       coastal resorts
       <a href="/wiki/Golden_Sands" title="Golden Sands">
        Golden Sands
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sunny_Beach" title="Sunny Beach">
        Sunny Beach
       </a>
       and winter resorts
       <a href="/wiki/Bansko" title="Bansko">
        Bansko
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pamporovo" title="Pamporovo">
        Pamporovo
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Borovets" title="Borovets">
        Borovets
       </a>
       are some of the locations most visited by tourists.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-general_tourism_230-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-general_tourism-230">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
        Science and technology
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Bulgaria" title="Science and technology in Bulgaria">
        Science and technology in Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blue_Gene_main.JPG">
         <img alt="An IBM Blue Gene/P supercomputer used by several Bulgarian scientific organisations" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3888" data-file-width="2592" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Blue_Gene_main.JPG/170px-Blue_Gene_main.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Blue_Gene_main.JPG/255px-Blue_Gene_main.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Blue_Gene_main.JPG/340px-Blue_Gene_main.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Blue_Gene_main.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <a href="/wiki/Supercomputer" title="Supercomputer">
          supercomputer
         </a>
         cabinet at NCSA
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria spends 0.95% of GDP on research and development.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
        <a href="#cite_note-236">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Chronic underinvestment in research since 1990 forced many scientific professionals to leave the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
        <a href="#cite_note-237">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a result, Bulgaria scores low in terms of innovation, competitiveness and high-value added exports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
        <a href="#cite_note-238">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Principal areas of research and development are energy,
       <a href="/wiki/Nanotechnology" title="Nanotechnology">
        nanotechnology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">
        archaeology
       </a>
       and medicine.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-R&amp;D_cuts_240-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-R&amp;D_cuts-240">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Bulgarian Academy of Sciences">
        Bulgarian Academy of Sciences
       </a>
       (BAS) is the leading scientific establishment and employs most Bulgarian researchers in its numerous institutes. It has been active in the field of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_science" title="Space science">
        space science
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/RADOM-7" title="RADOM-7">
        RADOM-7
       </a>
       radiation monitoring experiments on the
       <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">
        International Space Station
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Chandrayaan-1" title="Chandrayaan-1">
        Chandrayaan-1
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and domestically developed space
       <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse" title="Greenhouse">
        greenhouses
       </a>
       on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mir_space_station" title="Mir space station">
        Mir space station
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
        <a href="#cite_note-244">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria became the
       <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_space_travel_by_nationality" title="Timeline of space travel by nationality">
        sixth country
       </a>
       in the world to have an astronaut in space with
       <a href="/wiki/Georgi_Ivanov" title="Georgi Ivanov">
        Georgi Ivanov
       </a>
       's flight on
       <a href="/wiki/Soyuz_33" title="Soyuz 33">
        Soyuz 33
       </a>
       in 1979. Bulgaria is an active member of
       <a href="/wiki/CERN" title="CERN">
        CERN
       </a>
       and has contributed to its activities with nearly 200 scientists since its accession in 1999.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
        <a href="#cite_note-245">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
        <a href="#cite_note-246">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 1980s Bulgaria was known as the "
       <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">
        Silicon Valley
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">
        Eastern Bloc
       </a>
       " because of its large-scale computing technology exports to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/COMECON" title="COMECON">
        COMECON
       </a>
       states.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Information_and_communication_technologies" title="Information and communication technologies">
        ICT
       </a>
       sector generates 10 per cent of GDP
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and employs the third-largest contingent of ICT specialists in the world. A
       <a href="/wiki/National_Center_for_Supercomputing_Applications_(Bulgaria)" title="National Center for Supercomputing Applications (Bulgaria)">
        National Centre for Supercomputing Applications
       </a>
       (NCSA) operates the only supercomputer in Southeastern Europe.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
        <a href="#cite_note-250">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Bulgarian Academy of Sciences">
        Bulgarian Academy of Sciences
       </a>
       is planning to buy another supercomputer in 2015 which will be used together with Hi-Tech SME's.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
        <a href="#cite_note-251">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Internet usage has increased rapidly since 2000—the number of users grew from 430,000 to 3.4 million (48 per cent penetration rate) in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Telephone services are widely available, and a central digital trunk line connects most regions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200614_253-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200614-253">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than 90 per cent of fixed lines are served by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Telecommunications_Company" title="Bulgarian Telecommunications Company">
        Bulgarian Telecommunications Company
       </a>
       (BTC),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
        <a href="#cite_note-254">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while mobile services are provided by three operators—
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mobiltel" title="Mobiltel">
        Mtel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Telenor_(Bulgaria)" title="Telenor (Bulgaria)">
        Telenor
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vivacom" title="Vivacom">
        Vivacom
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
        <a href="#cite_note-255">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
        Infrastructure
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Bulgaria" title="Energy in Bulgaria">
        Energy in Bulgaria
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Bulgaria" title="Transport in Bulgaria">
        Transport in Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trakiya_highway_04.jpg">
         <img alt="Trakiya motorway, one of the main national motorways" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Trakiya_highway_04.jpg/220px-Trakiya_highway_04.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Trakiya_highway_04.jpg/330px-Trakiya_highway_04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Trakiya_highway_04.jpg/440px-Trakiya_highway_04.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trakiya_highway_04.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Trakia_motorway" title="Trakia motorway">
          Trakia motorway
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria's strategic geographic location and well-developed energy sector make it a key European energy centre despite its lack of significant fossil fuel deposits.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Nearly 34 percent of its electricity is produced by the
       <a href="/wiki/Kozloduy_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plant">
        nuclear power station at Kozloduy
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
        <a href="#cite_note-257">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and public opinion strongly supports nuclear energy development.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
        <a href="#cite_note-258">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The rapid expansion of alternative energy sources such as wind and solar power stations
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
        <a href="#cite_note-259">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
       make Bulgaria one of the fastest-growing wind energy producers in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
        <a href="#cite_note-260">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country aims to produce 16 percent of its electricity from renewable energy sources by 2020.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
        <a href="#cite_note-261">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The national road network has a total length of 40,231 kilometres (24,998 mi),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       of which 39,587 kilometres (24,598 mi) are paved, and recently most major roads have recently been brought to standards. Railroads are a major mode of freight transportation, although highways carry a progressively larger share of freight. Bulgaria has 6,238 kilometres (3,876 mi) of railway track
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200614_253-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200614-253">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and currently a total of 81 kilometres (50 miles) of
       <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">
        high-speed lines
       </a>
       are in operation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
        <a href="#cite_note-263">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
        <a href="#cite_note-264">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
        <a href="#cite_note-266">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Rail links are available with Romania, Turkey, Greece, and Serbia, and express trains serve direct routes to
       <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">
        Kiev
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Minsk" title="Minsk">
        Minsk
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">
        Moscow
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">
        Saint Petersburg
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Sofia and Plovdiv are the country's air travel hubs, while Varna and Burgas are the principal maritime trade ports.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200614_253-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress200614-253">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Varna is also scheduled to be the first station on EU territory to receive natural gas through the
       <a href="/wiki/South_Stream" title="South Stream">
        South Stream
       </a>
       pipeline.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Bulgaria" title="Demographics of Bulgaria">
        Demographics of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The population of Bulgaria is 7,364,570 people according to the 2011 national census. The majority of the population, or 72.5 percent, reside in urban areas;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20113_269-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20113-269">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       approximately one-sixth of the total population is concentrated in Sofia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20117_270-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20117-270">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data201112_271-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data201112-271">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">
        Bulgarians
       </a>
       are the main ethnic group and comprise 84.8 percent of the population.
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turks_in_Bulgaria" title="Turks in Bulgaria">
        Turkish
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roma_in_Bulgaria" title="Roma in Bulgaria">
        Roma
       </a>
       minorities comprise 8.8 and 4.9 percent, respectively; some 40 smaller minorities comprise 0.7 percent, and 0.8 percent do not self-identify with an ethnic group.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20114_1-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20114-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">
         <tr style="background:none">
          <th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">
           Distribution of languages of Bulgaria (2001)
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
            <a href="#cite_note-272">
             [270]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </th>
         </tr>
         <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;">
          </td>
          <td style="padding:0 4px; text-align:right;">
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">
            Bulgarian
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:84.5%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           84.5%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
            Turkish
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:9.6%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           9.6%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">
            Roma (Gypsy)
           </a>
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:4.1%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           4.1%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           others
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:0.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">
           undeclared
          </td>
          <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
           <div style="background:DarkSlateGray; width:0.9%; overflow: hidden;">
           </div>
          </td>
          <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">
           0.9%
          </td>
         </tr>
        </table>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Language">
        Language
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       All ethnic groups speak
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">
        Bulgarian
       </a>
       , either as a first or as a second language. Bulgarian is the only language with official status and native for 85.2 percent of the population. The oldest written
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">
        Slavic
       </a>
       language, Bulgarian is distinguishable from the other languages in this group through certain grammatical peculiarities such as the lack of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Noun_cases" title="Noun cases">
        noun cases
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infinitives" title="Infinitives">
        infinitives
       </a>
       , and a suffixed
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Definite_article" title="Definite article">
        definite article
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
        <a href="#cite_note-274">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literacy_and_education">
        Literacy and education
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg/220px-Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg/330px-Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg/440px-Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Students_67a_lab4_1000.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Students at the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technical_University_of_Sofia" title="Technical University of Sofia">
          Technical University of Sofia
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Government estimates from 2003 put the literacy rate at 98.6 percent, with no significant difference between the sexes. Educational standards have been
       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Bulgaria" title="Education in Bulgaria">
        traditionally high
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20066_275-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20066-275">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       although still far from European benchmarks and in continuing deterioration for the past decade.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNICEF_276-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNICEF-276">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgarian students were among the highest-scoring in the world in terms of reading in 2001, performing better than their Canadian and German counterparts; by 2006, scores in reading, math and science had deteriorated. State expenditures for education are far below the European Union average.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNICEF_276-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UNICEF-276">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">
        PISA
       </a>
       study of 2015 found 41.5% of pupils in the 9th grade to be
       <a href="/wiki/Functional_illiteracy" title="Functional illiteracy">
        functionally illiterate
       </a>
       in reading, maths and science. Bulgaria ranked 45th out of 72 countries surveyed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
        <a href="#cite_note-277">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education,_Youth_and_Science_(Bulgaria)" title="Ministry of Education, Youth and Science (Bulgaria)">
        Ministry of Education, Youth and Science
       </a>
       partially funds public schools, colleges and universities, sets criteria for textbooks and oversees the publishing process. The State provides free education in primary and secondary public schools.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20066_275-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20066-275">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The educational process spans through 12 grades, where grades one through eight are primary and nine through twelve are secondary level. High schools can be technical, vocational, general or specialised in a certain discipline, while higher education consists of a 4-year
       <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">
        bachelor
       </a>
       degree and a 1-year master's degree.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
        <a href="#cite_note-278">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Special_Education_Bulgaria" title="Special Education Bulgaria">
        Special Education Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Bulgaria" title="Religion in Bulgaria">
        Religion in Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg/220px-Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg/330px-Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg/440px-Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Theophany_Crucession_in_Bulgaria.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bulgarian Orthodox
         <a href="/wiki/Epiphany_(holiday)" title="Epiphany (holiday)">
          Theophany
         </a>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crucession" title="Crucession">
          Crucession
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Constitution of Bulgaria defines it as a
       <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">
        secular state
       </a>
       with guaranteed religious freedom, but designates
       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">
        Orthodoxy
       </a>
       as a "traditional" religion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
        <a href="#cite_note-279">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Orthodox_Church" title="Bulgarian Orthodox Church">
        Bulgarian Orthodox Church
       </a>
       gained
       <a href="/wiki/Autocephaly" title="Autocephaly">
        autocephalous
       </a>
       status in 927 AD,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
        <a href="#cite_note-280">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
        <a href="#cite_note-281">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and currently has 12 dioceses and over 2,000 priests.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
       More than three-quarters of Bulgarians subscribe to Eastern Orthodoxy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20115_283-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20115-283">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">
        Sunni Muslims
       </a>
       are the second-largest community and constitute 10 percent of the religious makeup, although a majority of them are not observant and find the use of
       <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">
        Islamic veils
       </a>
       in schools unacceptable.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
        <a href="#cite_note-284">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Less than three percent are affiliated with
       <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Bulgaria" title="Religion in Bulgaria">
        other religions
       </a>
       , 11.8 percent do not self-identify with a religion and 21.8 percent refused to state their beliefs.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20115_283-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20115-283">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">
        Healthcare
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Bulgaria has
       <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Bulgaria" title="Health in Bulgaria">
        a universal healthcare
       </a>
       system financed by taxes and contributions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Health_system_285-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Health_system-285">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF) pays a gradually increasing portion of the costs of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primary_health_care" title="Primary health care">
        primary healthcare
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20067_286-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress20067-286">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Projected healthcare expenditures for 2013 amount to 4.1 percent of GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
        <a href="#cite_note-287">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The number of doctors is above the EU average with 181 physicians per 100,000 people,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
        <a href="#cite_note-288">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but distribution by fields of practice is uneven, there is a severe shortage of nurses and other medical personnel, and the quality of most medical facilities is poor.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Personnel shortages in some fields are so severe that patients resort to seeking treatment in neighboring countries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria ranks 121st globally by average life expectancy, which stands at 74.5 years for both genders.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
        <a href="#cite_note-291">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The primary causes of death are similar to those in other industrialised countries, mainly
       <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">
        cardiovascular diseases
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Neoplasm" title="Neoplasm">
        neoplasms
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Respiratory" title="Respiratory">
        respiratory
       </a>
       diseases.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Health_system_285-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Health_system-285">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Population_growth_and_birthrates">
        Population growth and birthrates
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Bulgaria is in a state of demographic crisis.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BNR_crisis_293-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BNR_crisis-293">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has had negative population growth since the early 1990s, when the economic collapse caused a long-lasting emigration wave.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DW_Entry_294-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DW_Entry-294">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some 937,000 to 1,200,000 people—mostly young adults—left the country by 2005.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DW_Entry_294-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-DW_Entry-294">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
        total fertility rate
       </a>
       (TFR) was estimated in 2013 at 1.43 children born/woman, which is below the replacement rate of 2.1.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
        <a href="#cite_note-296">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A third of all households consist of only one person and 75.5 percent of families do not have children under the age of 16.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BNR_crisis_293-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-BNR_crisis-293">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Consequently, population growth and birth rates are among the lowest in the world
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
        <a href="#cite_note-297">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while death rates are among the highest.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The majority of children are born to unmarried women (of all births 57.4 percent were outside marriage in 2012).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
        <a href="#cite_note-300">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="navbox">
       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
