      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Bulgaria" title="Culture of Bulgaria">
        Culture of Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg">
         <img alt="Thracian golden wreath exhibited in the National Historical Museum" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2000" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg/170px-Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg/255px-Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg/340px-Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sofia_-_Odrysian_Wreath_from_Golyamata_Mogila.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Thracia" title="Thracia">
          Thracian
         </a>
         golden
         <a href="/wiki/Wreath" title="Wreath">
          wreath
         </a>
         in the
         <a href="/wiki/National_Historical_Museum_(Bulgaria)" title="National Historical Museum (Bulgaria)">
          National Historical Museum
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3456" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG/220px-Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG/330px-Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG/440px-Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bulgarian_folk_dancers_and_musicians_in_Brussels.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bulgarian folk dancers and musicians in traditional attire
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rila_Monastery,_August_2013.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2460" data-file-width="3690" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Rila_Monastery%2C_August_2013.jpg/220px-Rila_Monastery%2C_August_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Rila_Monastery%2C_August_2013.jpg/330px-Rila_Monastery%2C_August_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Rila_Monastery%2C_August_2013.jpg/440px-Rila_Monastery%2C_August_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rila_Monastery,_August_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monastery_of_Saint_Ivan_of_Rila" title="Monastery of Saint Ivan of Rila">
          Monastery of Saint Ivan of Rila
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bgnr.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="569" data-file-width="850" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bgnr.jpg/220px-Bgnr.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bgnr.jpg/330px-Bgnr.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bgnr.jpg/440px-Bgnr.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bgnr.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Traditional Bulgarian all-male
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Horo_(dance)" title="Horo (dance)">
          horo
         </a>
         danced in the ice-cold river on
         <a href="/wiki/Epiphany_(holiday)" title="Epiphany (holiday)">
          Epiphany
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Bulgaria" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Bulgaria">
        Nine historical and natural objects
       </a>
       have been inscribed in the list of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">
        UNESCO World Heritage Sites
       </a>
       : the
       <a href="/wiki/Madara_Rider" title="Madara Rider">
        Madara Rider
       </a>
       , the Thracian tombs in
       <a href="/wiki/Thracian_Tomb_of_Sveshtari" title="Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari">
        Sveshtari
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Thracian_Tomb_of_Kazanlak" title="Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak">
        Kazanlak
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Boyana_Church" title="Boyana Church">
        Boyana Church
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Rila_Monastery" title="Rila Monastery">
        Rila Monastery
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Rock-hewn_Churches_of_Ivanovo" title="Rock-hewn Churches of Ivanovo">
        Rock-hewn Churches of Ivanovo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pirin_National_Park" title="Pirin National Park">
        Pirin National Park
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Srebarna_Nature_Reserve" title="Srebarna Nature Reserve">
        Sreburna Nature Reserve
       </a>
       and the ancient city of
       <a href="/wiki/Nesebar" title="Nesebar">
        Nesebar
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
        <a href="#cite_note-302">
         [300]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Nestinarstvo" title="Nestinarstvo">
        Nestinarstvo
       </a>
       , a ritual fire-dance of Thracian origin,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
        <a href="#cite_note-303">
         [301]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is included in the list of
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">
        UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
        <a href="#cite_note-304">
         [302]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Fire is an essential element of Bulgarian folklore, used to banish evil spirits and diseases. Bulgarian folklore personifies illnesses as witches and has a wide range of creatures, including
       <a href="/wiki/Slavic_dragon" title="Slavic dragon">
        lamya
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Samodiva_(mythology)" title="Samodiva (mythology)">
        samodiva
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supernatural_beings_in_Slavic_folklore" title="Supernatural beings in Slavic folklore">
        veela
       </a>
       ) and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karakoncolos" title="Karakoncolos">
        karakondzhul
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
        <a href="#cite_note-305">
         [303]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some of the customs and rituals against these spirits have survived and are still practised, most notably the
       <a href="/wiki/Kukeri" title="Kukeri">
        kukeri
       </a>
       and survakari.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
        <a href="#cite_note-306">
         [304]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Martenitsa" title="Martenitsa">
        Martenitsa
       </a>
       is also widely celebrated.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
        <a href="#cite_note-307">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavic_culture" title="Slavic culture">
        Slavic culture
       </a>
       was centred in both the First and Second Bulgarian Empires during much of the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Preslav_Literary_School" title="Preslav Literary School">
        Preslav
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ohrid_Literary_School" title="Ohrid Literary School">
        Ohrid
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tarnovo_Literary_School" title="Tarnovo Literary School">
        Tarnovo
       </a>
       literary schools exerted considerable cultural influence over the Eastern Orthodox world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
        <a href="#cite_note-308">
         [306]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
        <a href="#cite_note-309">
         [307]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
        <a href="#cite_note-310">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many languages in Eastern Europe and Asia use
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyrillic" title="Cyrillic">
        Cyrillic
       </a>
       script, which originated in the Preslav Literary School around the 9th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
        <a href="#cite_note-311">
         [309]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The medieval advancement in the arts and letters ended with the Ottoman conquest when many masterpieces were destroyed, and artistic activities did not re-emerge until the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Revival" title="Bulgarian National Revival">
        National Revival
       </a>
       in the 19th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cultural_life_312-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cultural_life-312">
         [310]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After the Liberation, Bulgarian literature quickly adopted European literary styles such as
       <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">
        Romanticism
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">
        Symbolism
       </a>
       . Since the beginning of the 20th century, several Bulgarian authors, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Vazov" title="Ivan Vazov">
        Ivan Vazov
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pencho_Slaveykov" title="Pencho Slaveykov">
        Pencho Slaveykov
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Peyo_Yavorov" title="Peyo Yavorov">
        Peyo Yavorov
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Yordan_Radichkov" title="Yordan Radichkov">
        Yordan Radichkov
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tzvetan_Todorov" title="Tzvetan Todorov">
        Tzvetan Todorov
       </a>
       have gained prominence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
        <a href="#cite_note-313">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
        <a href="#cite_note-314">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1981 Bulgarian-born writer
       <a href="/wiki/Elias_Canetti" title="Elias Canetti">
        Elias Canetti
       </a>
       was awarded the
       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">
        Nobel Prize in Literature
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-litenc_315-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-litenc-315">
         [313]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Bulgarian folk music is by far the most extensive traditional art and has slowly developed throughout the ages as a fusion of Eastern and Western influences. It contains Far Eastern, Oriental, medieval Eastern Orthodox and standard Western European tonalities and modes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
        <a href="#cite_note-316">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The music has a distinctive sound and uses a wide range of traditional instruments, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Gadulka" title="Gadulka">
        gadulka
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Gaida" title="Gaida">
        gaida
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bagpipe" title="Bagpipe">
        bagpipe
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Kaval" title="Kaval">
        kaval
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Davul" title="Davul">
        tupan
       </a>
       . One of its most distinguishing features is
       <i>
        extended rhythmical time
       </i>
       , which has no equivalent in the rest of European music.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CENTCOM_22-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-CENTCOM-22">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_State_Television_Female_Vocal_Choir" title="Bulgarian State Television Female Vocal Choir">
        State Television Female Vocal Choir
       </a>
       is the most famous performing folk ensemble, and received a
       <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">
        Grammy Award
       </a>
       in 1990.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
        <a href="#cite_note-317">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria's written musical composition can be traced back to the early Middle Ages and the works of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yoan_Kukuzel" title="Yoan Kukuzel">
        Yoan Kukuzel
       </a>
       (c. 1280–1360).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
        <a href="#cite_note-318">
         [316]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Classical music, opera and ballet are represented by composers
       <a href="/wiki/Emanuil_Manolov" title="Emanuil Manolov">
        Emanuil Manolov
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pancho_Vladigerov" title="Pancho Vladigerov">
        Pancho Vladigerov
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Georgi_Atanasov_(composer)" title="Georgi Atanasov (composer)">
        Georgi Atanasov
       </a>
       and singers
       <a href="/wiki/Ghena_Dimitrova" title="Ghena Dimitrova">
        Ghena Dimitrova
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Boris_Christoff" title="Boris Christoff">
        Boris Hristov
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nicolai_Ghiaurov" title="Nicolai Ghiaurov">
        Nikolay Gyaurov
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
        <a href="#cite_note-319">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
        <a href="#cite_note-320">
         [318]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
        <a href="#cite_note-321">
         [319]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
        <a href="#cite_note-322">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
        <a href="#cite_note-323">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgarian performers have gained popularity in several other genres like
       <a href="/wiki/Progressive_rock" title="Progressive rock">
        progressive rock
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/FSB_(band)" title="FSB (band)">
        FSB
       </a>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Electropop" title="Electropop">
        electropop
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Mira_Aroyo" title="Mira Aroyo">
        Mira Aroyo
       </a>
       ) and
       <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">
        jazz
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Milcho_Leviev" title="Milcho Leviev">
        Milcho Leviev
       </a>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       The religious visual arts heritage includes
       <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">
        frescoes
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mural" title="Mural">
        murals
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Icon" title="Icon">
        icons
       </a>
       , many produced by the medieval
       <a href="/wiki/Painting_of_the_Tarnovo_Artistic_School" title="Painting of the Tarnovo Artistic School">
        Tarnovo Artistic School
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
        <a href="#cite_note-324">
         [322]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Dimitrov" title="Vladimir Dimitrov">
        Vladimir Dimitrov
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Diulgheroff" title="Nikolay Diulgheroff">
        Nikolay Diulgheroff
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christo" title="Christo">
        Christo
       </a>
       are some of the most famous modern Bulgarian artists.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cultural_life_312-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cultural_life-312">
         [310]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Film industry remains weak: in 2010, Bulgaria produced three feature films and two documentaries with public funding. Cultural events are advertised in the largest media outlets, including the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Radio" title="Bulgarian National Radio">
        Bulgarian National Radio
       </a>
       , and daily newspapers
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dneven_Trud" title="Dneven Trud">
         Dneven Trud
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dnevnik_(Bulgaria)" title="Dnevnik (Bulgaria)">
         Dnevnik
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/24_Chasa" title="24 Chasa">
         24 Chasa
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
        <a href="#cite_note-325">
         [323]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       While major sections of
       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Bulgaria" title="Media of Bulgaria">
        Bulgaria's media
       </a>
       are controlled by state entities, including
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Television" title="Bulgarian National Television">
        Bulgarian National Television
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_National_Radio" title="Bulgarian National Radio">
        Bulgarian National Radio
       </a>
       , and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Telegraph_Agency" title="Bulgarian Telegraph Agency">
        Bulgarian Telegraph Agency
       </a>
       , reporting is generally deemed to be unbiased by direct government interference, although there is no specific legislation to maintain this.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
        <a href="#cite_note-326">
         [324]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Written media has no legal restrictions,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-landscape_327-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-landscape-327">
         [325]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a large number of private television and radio stations also exist. Despite this, traditional Bulgarian media outlets are experiencing negative economic and political pressures, and instances of self-censorship have emerged. Meanwhile, internet media is growing in popularity due to its lack of censorship and the diversity of content and opinions it presents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-media_328-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-media-328">
         [326]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_cuisine" title="Bulgarian cuisine">
        Bulgarian cuisine
       </a>
       is similar to those of other Balkan countries and demonstrates a strong Turkish and Greek influence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cuisine_329-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cuisine-329">
         [327]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">
        Yogurt
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lukanka" title="Lukanka">
        lukanka
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Banitsa" title="Banitsa">
        banitsa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Shopska_salad" title="Shopska salad">
        shopska salad
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyutenitsa" title="Lyutenitsa">
        lyutenitsa
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kozunak" title="Kozunak">
        kozunak
       </a>
       are among the best-known local foods. Oriental dishes such as
       <a href="/wiki/Moussaka" title="Moussaka">
        moussaka
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gyuvech" title="Gyuvech">
        gyuvech
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Baklava" title="Baklava">
        baklava
       </a>
       are also present. Meat consumption is lower than the European average, given a notable preference for a large variety of salads.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cuisine_329-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cuisine-329">
         [327]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Bulgaria is also famous for its wines and spirits. Until 1989, Bulgaria was the world's second-largest wine exporter.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
        <a href="#cite_note-330">
         [328]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016 it is the world 22nd in wine production.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
        <a href="#cite_note-331">
         [329]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For 2016 Bulgaria produced 128m litres of wine, 62m litres expected for export, mainly to Romania, Poland and Russia.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
        <a href="#cite_note-332">
         [330]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 5 most popular grapes used for production of
       <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_wine" title="Bulgarian wine">
        Bulgarian wine
       </a>
       are
       <a href="/wiki/Mavrud" title="Mavrud">
        Mavrud
       </a>
       , Rubin,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shiroka_Melnishka_Losa" title="Shiroka Melnishka Losa">
        Shiroka Melnishka Losa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dimiat" title="Dimiat">
        Dimiat
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Misket_Cherven" title="Misket Cherven">
        Cherven Misket
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
        <a href="#cite_note-333">
         [331]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Rakia" title="Rakia">
        Rakia
       </a>
       is a traditional fruit
       <a href="/wiki/Brandy" title="Brandy">
        brandy
       </a>
       which was consumed in Bulgaria as early as the 14th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
        <a href="#cite_note-334">
         [332]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="UNESCO_World_Heritage">
        UNESCO World Heritage
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="noviewer thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px">
        <div style="position:relative;width:300px;border:1px solid lightgray">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_location_map.svg" title="UNSECO World Heritage in Bulgaria">
          <img alt="UNSECO World Heritage in Bulgaria" data-file-height="1036" data-file-width="1642" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Bulgaria_location_map.svg/300px-Bulgaria_location_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Bulgaria_location_map.svg/450px-Bulgaria_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Bulgaria_location_map.svg/600px-Bulgaria_location_map.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
         </a>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:51.515%;left:18.088%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Boyana Church" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Boyana Church" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;left:5px;text-align:left">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:left">
            <a href="/wiki/Boyana_Church" title="Boyana Church">
             Boyana Church
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:34.018%;left:73.807%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Madara Rider" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Madara Rider" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;right:5px;text-align:right">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:right">
            <a href="/wiki/Madara_Rider" title="Madara Rider">
             Madara Rider
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:21.367%;left:57.163%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Rock-hewn Churches of Ivanovo" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Rock-hewn Churches of Ivanovo" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;right:5px;text-align:right">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:right">
            <a href="/wiki/Rock-hewn_Churches_of_Ivanovo" title="Rock-hewn Churches of Ivanovo">
             Rock-hewn Churches of Ivanovo
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:53.763%;left:48.517%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;left:5px;text-align:left">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:left">
            <a href="/wiki/Thracian_Tomb_of_Kazanlak" title="Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak">
             Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:52.788%;left:82.838%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Nesebar" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Nesebar" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;right:5px;text-align:right">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:right">
            <a href="/wiki/Nesebar" title="Nesebar">
             Nesebar
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:70.303%;left:16.176%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Rila Monastery" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Rila Monastery" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;left:5px;text-align:left">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:left">
            <a href="/wiki/Rila_Monastery" title="Rila Monastery">
             Rila Monastery
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:19.879%;left:68.529%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/8px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/12px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/16px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;left:5px;text-align:left">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:left">
            <a href="/wiki/Thracian_Tomb_of_Sveshtari" title="Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari">
             Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:82.818%;left:20.588%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Pirin National Park" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/8px-Green_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/12px-Green_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/16px-Green_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Pirin National Park" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;left:5px;text-align:left">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:left">
            <a href="/wiki/Pirin_National_Park" title="Pirin National Park">
             Pirin National Park
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div style="position:absolute;top:10.152%;left:72.706%">
          <div style="position:absolute;left:-4px;top:-4px;line-height:0">
           <img alt="Srebarna Reserve" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="8" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/8px-Green_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/12px-Green_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/16px-Green_pog.svg.png 2x" title="Srebarna Reserve" width="8"/>
          </div>
          <div style="font-size:70%;line-height:110%;position:absolute;width:6em;top:-0.75em;right:5px;text-align:right">
           <span style="padding:1px;float:right">
            <a href="/wiki/Srebarna_Nature_Reserve" title="Srebarna Nature Reserve">
             Srebarna Reserve
            </a>
           </span>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bulgaria_location_map.svg" title="File:Bulgaria location map.svg">
          </a>
         </div>
         UNSECO World Heritage cultural sights in Bulgaria
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Green_pog.svg">
          <img alt="Green pog.svg" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="10" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/10px-Green_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/15px-Green_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Green_pog.svg/20px-Green_pog.svg.png 2x" width="10"/>
         </a>
         : Natural site
         <br/>
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Red_pog.svg">
          <img alt="Red pog.svg" data-file-height="64" data-file-width="64" height="10" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/10px-Red_pog.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/15px-Red_pog.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Red_pog.svg/20px-Red_pog.svg.png 2x" width="10"/>
         </a>
         : Cultural site
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural">
        Cultural
       </span>
      </h4>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Boyana_Church" title="Boyana Church">
         Boyana Church
        </a>
        (1979)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Madara_Rider" title="Madara Rider">
         Madara Rider
        </a>
        (1979)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock-Hewn_Churches_of_Ivanovo" title="Rock-Hewn Churches of Ivanovo">
         Rock-Hewn Churches of Ivanovo
        </a>
        (1979)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Thracian_Tomb_of_Kazanlak" title="Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak">
         Thracian Tomb of Kazanlak
        </a>
        (1979)
       </li>
       <li>
        Ancient City of
        <a href="/wiki/Nesebar" title="Nesebar">
         Nesebar
        </a>
        (1983)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Rila_Monastery" title="Rila Monastery">
         Rila Monastery
        </a>
        (1983)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Thracian_Tomb_of_Sveshtari" title="Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari">
         Thracian Tomb of Sveshtari
        </a>
        (1985)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Natural">
        Natural
       </span>
      </h4>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Pirin_National_Park" title="Pirin National Park">
         Pirin National Park
        </a>
        (1983)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Srebarna_Nature_Reserve" title="Srebarna Nature Reserve">
         Srebarna Nature Reserve
        </a>
        (1983)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="512" height="39" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           needs additional citations for
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
            verification
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please help
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bulgaria&amp;action=edit">
            improve this article
           </a>
           by
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">
            adding citations to reliable sources
           </a>
           . Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.
          </span>

           <i>
            (March 2018)
           </i>
          </small>
          <small class="hide-when-compact">

            </a>

           </i>
          </small>

      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Bulgaria" title="Sport in Bulgaria">
        Sport in Bulgaria
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Bulgaria performs well in sports such as
       <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">
        wrestling
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">
        weight-lifting
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">
        boxing
       </a>
       , gymnastics,
       <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">
        volleyball
       </a>
       , football and
       <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">
        tennis
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sport_335-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sport-335">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country fields one of the leading men's volleyball teams, ranked sixth in the world according to the 2013
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIVB" title="FIVB">
        FIVB
       </a>
       rankings.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
        <a href="#cite_note-336">
         [334]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        Football
       </a>
       is by far the most popular sport.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sport_335-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sport-335">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Some famous players are
       <a href="/wiki/Dimitar_Berbatov" title="Dimitar Berbatov">
        Dimitar Berbatov
       </a>
       , former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manchester_United" title="Manchester United">
        Manchester United
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur" title="Tottenham Hotspur">
        Tottenham Hotspur
       </a>
       forward,
       <a href="/wiki/Georgi_Asparuhov" title="Georgi Asparuhov">
        Georgi Asparuhov
       </a>
       , former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Levski_Sofia" title="Levski Sofia">
        Levski Sofia
       </a>
       forward and
       <a href="/wiki/Hristo_Stoichkov" title="Hristo Stoichkov">
        Hristo Stoichkov
       </a>
       , winner of the Golden Boot and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Ball_(FIFA)" title="Golden Ball (FIFA)">
        Golden Ball
       </a>
       and the most successful Bulgarian player of all time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337">
        <a href="#cite_note-337">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prominent domestic clubs include
       <a href="/wiki/PFC_CSKA_Sofia" title="PFC CSKA Sofia">
        PFC CSKA Sofia
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338">
        <a href="#cite_note-338">
         [336]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339">
        <a href="#cite_note-339">
         [337]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/PFC_Levski_Sofia" title="PFC Levski Sofia">
        PFC Levski Sofia
       </a>
       . The best performance of the national team at FIFA World Cup finals came
       <a href="/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1994 FIFA World Cup">
        in 1994
       </a>
       , when it advanced to the semi-finals by defeating consecutively
       <a href="/wiki/Greece_national_football_team" title="Greece national football team">
        Greece
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team" title="Argentina national football team">
        Argentina
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team" title="Mexico national football team">
        Mexico
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">
        Germany
       </a>
       , finishing fourth.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sport_335-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Sport-335">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Bulgaria has participated in most Olympic competitions since its first appearance at the
       <a href="/wiki/1896_Summer_Olympics" title="1896 Summer Olympics">
        1896 games
       </a>
       , when it was represented by
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Champaud" title="Charles Champaud">
        Charles Champaud
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
        <a href="#cite_note-340">
         [338]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The country has won a total of 218 medals: 52 gold, 86 silver, and 80 bronze,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341">
        <a href="#cite_note-341">
         [339]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which puts it in 24th place in the
       <a href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Olympic Games medal table">
        all-time ranking
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Stefka_Kostadinova" title="Stefka Kostadinova">
        Stefka Kostadinova
       </a>
       is the reigning
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_world_records_in_athletics" title="List of world records in athletics">
        world record
       </a>
       holder in the women's high jump at 2.09 metres (6 feet 10 inches), which she jumped during the
       <a href="/wiki/1987_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="1987 World Championships in Athletics">
        1987 World Championships in Athletics
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">
        Rome
       </a>
       . Her world record is one of the oldest in modern athletics. Altogether Kostadinova set seven world records – three outdoors and four indoors. She also holds the women's world record for having jumped over 2.00 metres (6 feet 7 inches) 197 times.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Yordanka_Donkova" title="Yordanka Donkova">
        Yordanka Donkova
       </a>
       is a former
       <a href="/wiki/Hurdling" title="Hurdling">
        hurdling
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Athletics_(sport)" title="Athletics (sport)">
        athlete
       </a>
       , notable for winning an Olympic
       <a href="/wiki/Gold_medal" title="Gold medal">
        gold medal
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Bronze_medal" title="Bronze medal">
        bronze medal
       </a>
       as well as 9 medals at European
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Indoor_Championships_in_Athletics" title="European Indoor Championships in Athletics">
        indoor
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Championships_in_Athletics" title="European Championships in Athletics">
        outdoor
       </a>
       championships. Donkova set four
       <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_100_metres_hurdles_world_record_progression" title="Women's 100 metres hurdles world record progression">
        100 m hurdles world records
       </a>
       in 1986. Her fifth world record, a time of 12.21 set in 1988, stood until 2016.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Petar_Stoychev" title="Petar Stoychev">
        Petar Stoychev
       </a>
       is a long distance
       <a href="/wiki/Marathon_swimming" title="Marathon swimming">
        marathon swimmer
       </a>
       who set a new swimming world record for crossing the
       <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">
        English Channel
       </a>
       in 2007.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Maria_Gigova" title="Maria Gigova">
        Maria Gigova
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Maria_Petrova_(rhythmic_gymnast)" title="Maria Petrova (rhythmic gymnast)">
        Maria Petrova
       </a>
       have each held a record of three world-titles in
       <a href="/wiki/Rhythmic_gymnastics" title="Rhythmic gymnastics">
        rhythmic gymnastics
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Kaloyan Mahlyanov (Калоян Махлянов), known as
       <a href="/wiki/Koto%C5%8Dsh%C5%AB_Katsunori" title="Kotoōshū Katsunori">
        Kotoōshū Katsunori
       </a>
       is a former professional
       <a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">
        sumo
       </a>
       wrestler who became the first European to earn the title
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ozeki" title="Ozeki">
        ozeki
       </a>
       in Japan.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Veselin_Topalov" title="Veselin Topalov">
        Veselin Topalov
       </a>
       became FIDE
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Chess_Champion" title="World Chess Champion">
        World Chess Champion
       </a>
       by winning the
       <a href="/wiki/FIDE_World_Chess_Championship_2005" title="FIDE World Chess Championship 2005">
        FIDE World Chess Championship 2005
       </a>
       . He lost his title in the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2006" title="World Chess Championship 2006">
        World Chess Championship 2006
       </a>
       against
       <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Kramnik" title="Vladimir Kramnik">
        Vladimir Kramnik
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The Bulgarian national volleyball team has regularly featured in the Top 10, and has earned
       <a href="/wiki/Silver_medal" title="Silver medal">
        silver medals
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics" title="1980 Summer Olympics">
        1980 Summer Olympics
       </a>
       , the 1970
       <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Men%27s_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship">
        FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship
       </a>
       and the 1951
       <a href="/wiki/Men%27s_European_Volleyball_Championship" title="Men's European Volleyball Championship">
        European Championship
       </a>
       , as well as numerous bronze medals, including at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2007_FIVB_Men%27s_World_Cup" title="2007 FIVB Men's World Cup">
        2007 World Cup
       </a>
       in Japan.
      </p>

        <ol class="references">
         <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20114-1">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20114_1-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTENSI_Census_data20114_1-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>

         <li id="cite_note-16">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            <a href="#cite_ref-16">
             ^

           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Slavchev, Vladimir (2004–2005).
            <a class="external text" href="http://revistapontica.files.wordpress.com/2009/10/pontica-37-38-pag-9-20.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Monuments of the final phase of Cultures Hamangia and Savia on the territory of Bulgaria
             </i>
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            .
            <i>
             Revista Pontica
            </i>
            . 37–38. pp. 9–20
            <span class="reference-accessdate">

             </span>

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Monuments+of+the+final+phase+of+Cultures+Hamangia+and+Savia+on+the+territory+of+Bulgaria&amp;rft.pages=9-20&amp;rft.date=2004%2F2005&amp;rft.aulast=Slavchev&amp;rft.aufirst=Vladimir&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Frevistapontica.files.wordpress.com%2F2009%2F10%2Fpontica-37-38-pag-9-20.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-17">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-17">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book" id="CITEREFChapman2000">
            Chapman, John (2000).
            <i>
             Fragmentation in Archaeology: People, Places, and Broken Objects
            </i>
            . Routledge. p. 239.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-15803-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-15803-9">
             978-0-415-15803-9
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Fragmentation+in+Archaeology%3A+People%2C+Places%2C+and+Broken+Objects&amp;rft.pages=239&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-15803-9&amp;rft.aulast=Chapman&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-18">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-18">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            Roberts, Benjamin W.; Thornton, Christopher P. (2009).
            <a class="external text" href="https://britishmuseum.academia.edu/BenjaminRoberts/Papers/340888/Development_of_metallurgy_in_Eurasia" rel="nofollow">
             "Development of metallurgy in Eurasia"
            </a>
            . Department of Prehistory and Europe,
            <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">
             British Museum
            </a>
            . p. 1015
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              8 June
             </span>
             2012
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             In contrast, the earliest exploitation and working of gold occurs in the Balkans during the mid-fifth millennium BC, several centuries after the earliest known copper smelting. This is demonstrated most spectacularly in the various objects adorning the burials at Varna, Bulgaria (Renfrew 1986; Highamet al. 2007). In contrast, the earliest gold objects found in Southwest Asia date only to the beginning of the fourth millennium BC as at Nahal Qanah in Israel (Golden 2009), suggesting that gold exploitation may have been a Southeast European invention, albeit a short-lived one.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Development+of+metallurgy+in+Eurasia&amp;rft.pages=1015&amp;rft.pub=Department+of+Prehistory+and+Europe%2C+British+Museum&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.aulast=Roberts&amp;rft.aufirst=Benjamin+W.&amp;rft.au=Thornton%2C+Christopher+P.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbritishmuseum.academia.edu%2FBenjaminRoberts%2FPapers%2F340888%2FDevelopment_of_metallurgy_in_Eurasia&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-19">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-19">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Sigfried J. de Laet, ed. (1996).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=BnY0KYbJC6wC&amp;pg=PA97&amp;dq=history+of+metallurgy+bulgaria#v=onepage&amp;q=bulgaria&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              History of Humanity: From the Third Millennium to the Seventh Century BC
             </i>
            </a>
            . UNESCO / Routledge. p. 99.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-92-3-102811-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-92-3-102811-3">
             978-92-3-102811-3
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              8 June
             </span>
             2012
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             The first major gold-working centre was situated at the mouth of the Danube, on the shores of the Black Sea in Bulgaria ...
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+Humanity%3A+From+the+Third+Millennium+to+the+Seventh+Century+BC&amp;rft.pages=99&amp;rft.pub=UNESCO+%2F+Routledge&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-92-3-102811-3&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DBnY0KYbJC6wC%26pg%3DPA97%26dq%3Dhistory%2Bof%2Bmetallurgy%2Bbulgaria%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dbulgaria%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-20">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-20">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Grande, Lance (2009).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=RnE9Fa4pbn0C&amp;pg=PA290&amp;dq=varna+necropolis+oldest#v=onepage&amp;q=varna%20necropolis%20oldest&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Gems and gemstones: Timeless natural beauty of the mineral world
             </i>
            </a>
            . The University of Chicago Press. p. 292.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-226-30511-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-226-30511-0">
             978-0-226-30511-0
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             The oldest known gold jewelry in the world is from an archaeological site in Varna Necropolis, Bulgaria, and is over 6,000 years old (radiocarbon dated between 4,600BC and 4,200BC).
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Gems+and+gemstones%3A+Timeless+natural+beauty+of+the+mineral+world&amp;rft.pages=292&amp;rft.pub=The+University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-226-30511-0&amp;rft.aulast=Grande&amp;rft.aufirst=Lance&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DRnE9Fa4pbn0C%26pg%3DPA290%26dq%3Dvarna%2Bnecropolis%2Boldest%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dvarna%2520necropolis%2520oldest%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-21">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-21">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/arcnat/harsova/en/dobro3.htm" rel="nofollow">
             "The Gumelnita Culture"
            </a>
            . Government of France
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              4 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>

            <q>
             The Necropolis at Varna is an important site in understanding this culture.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Gumelnita+Culture&amp;rft.pub=Government+of+France&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.culture.gouv.fr%2Fculture%2Farcnat%2Fharsova%2Fen%2Fdobro3.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

         <li id="cite_note-24">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-24">
             ^

           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Boardman, John; Edwards, I.E.S.; Sollberger, E. (1982).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=vXljf8JqmkoC&amp;pg=PA53&amp;dq=Yet+we+cannot+identify+the+Thracians#v=onepage&amp;q=Yet%20we%20cannot%20identify%20the%20Thracians&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

              The Cambridge Ancient History – part1: The Prehistory of the Balkans, the Middle East and the Aegean World, Tenth to Eighth Centuries BC
             </i>
            </a>
            .
            <b>
             3
            </b>
            . Cambridge University Press. p. 53.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0521224969" title="Special:BookSources/0521224969">
             0521224969
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             Yet we cannot identify the Thracians at that remote period, because we do not know for certain whether the Thracian and Illyrian tribes had separated by then. It is safer to speak of Proto-Thracians from whom there developed in the Iron Age...
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cambridge+Ancient+History+%E2%80%93+part1%3A+The+Prehistory+of+the+Balkans%2C+the+Middle+East+and+the+Aegean+World%2C+Tenth+to+Eighth+Centuries+BC&amp;rft.pages=53&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rft.isbn=0521224969&amp;rft.aulast=Boardman&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.au=Edwards%2C+I.E.S.&amp;rft.au=Sollberger%2C+E.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DvXljf8JqmkoC%26pg%3DPA53%26dq%3DYet%2Bwe%2Bcannot%2Bidentify%2Bthe%2BThracians%23v%3Donepage%26q%3DYet%2520we%2520cannot%2520identify%2520the%2520Thracians%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

            </span>
           </span>
          </span>

         <li id="cite_note-25">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

             ^

          <span class="reference-text">

             (...) In addition, the Persians gained Thrace (modern-day Bulgaria)
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Making+Europe%3A+The+Story+of+the+West&amp;rft.pages=57&amp;rft.edition=2&amp;rft.pub=Cengage+Learning&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1111841317&amp;rft.au=Kidner&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3D1_E_CQAAQBAJ%26dq%3Ddarius%2Bconquer%2Bbulgaria&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-26">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-26">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Thonemann, Peter; Price, Simon (2010).
            <i>
             The Birth of Classical Europe: A History from Troy to Augustine
            </i>
            . Penguin UK.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0141946863" title="Special:BookSources/978-0141946863">
             978-0141946863
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             Darius extended the eastern and western boundaries of the empire still further, conquering the Indus Valley and much of modern Bulgaria (ancient Thrace)
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Birth+of+Classical+Europe%3A+A+History+from+Troy+to+Augustine&amp;rft.pub=Penguin+UK&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0141946863&amp;rft.aulast=Thonemann&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rft.au=Price%2C+Simon&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_343–345-27">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135–138,_343–345_27-0">

              </b>

         <li id="cite_note-29">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-29">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0oKx4FyAOOQC&amp;pg=PA221&amp;dq=Teres+I+odrysian+kingdom+persian&amp;hl=nl&amp;sa=X&amp;ei=FgyaVN-zN4LXavePguAG&amp;ved=0CC8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&amp;q=Teres%20I%20odrysian%20kingdom%20persian&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">

             </span>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Expedition+of+Cyrus&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D0oKx4FyAOOQC%26pg%3DPA221%26dq%3DTeres%2BI%2Bodrysian%2Bkingdom%2Bpersian%26hl%3Dnl%26sa%3DX%26ei%3DFgyaVN-zN4LXavePguAG%26ved%3D0CC8Q6AEwAg%23v%3Donepage%26q%3DTeres%2520I%2520odrysian%2520kingdom%2520persian%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-30">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-30">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Nagle, D. Brendan (2006).
            <i>
             Readings in Greek History: Sources and Interpretations
            </i>
            . Oxford University Press. p. 230.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-517825-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-19-517825-4">
             0-19-517825-4
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             However, one of the Thracian tribes, the Odrysians, succeeded in unifying the Thracians and creating a powerful state
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Readings+in+Greek+History%3A+Sources+and+Interpretations&amp;rft.pages=230&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=0-19-517825-4&amp;rft.aulast=Nagle&amp;rft.aufirst=D.+Brendan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-31">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-31">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Hornblower, Simon (2003).
            <i>
             The Oxford Classical Dictionary
            </i>
            . Oxford University Press. p. 1515.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-860641-9" title="Special:BookSources/0-19-860641-9">
             0-19-860641-9
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             Shortly afterwards the first King of the Odrysae, Teres attempted to carve an empire out of the territory occupied by the Thracian tribes (Thuc.2.29 and his sovereignty extended as far as the Euxine and the Hellespont)
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+Classical+Dictionary&amp;rft.pages=1515&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=0-19-860641-9&amp;rft.aulast=Hornblower&amp;rft.aufirst=Simon&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-32">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-32">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Ivanov, Lyubomir (2007).
            <a class="external text" href="http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Essential_History_of_Bulgaria_in_Seven_Pages">
             <i>
              ESSENTIAL HISTORY OF BULGARIA IN SEVEN PAGES
             </i>
            </a>
            . Bulgarian Academy of Sciences. p. 2
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             In particular, in the mid-4th century a group of Goths settled in the region of Nikopolis ad Istrum (present Nikyup near Veliko Tarnovo in northern Bulgaria), where their leader Bishop Wulfila (Ulfilas) invented the Gothic alphabet and translated the Holy Bible into Gothic to produce the first book written in Germanic language.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=ESSENTIAL+HISTORY+OF+BULGARIA+IN+SEVEN+PAGES&amp;rft.pages=2&amp;rft.pub=Bulgarian+Academy+of+Sciences&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.aulast=Ivanov&amp;rft.aufirst=Lyubomir&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fen.wikisource.org%2Fwiki%2FEssential_History_of_Bulgaria_in_Seven_Pages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-33">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-33">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Hock, Hans Heinrich; Joseph, Brian D. (1996).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=oGH-RCW1fzsC&amp;pg=PA49&amp;lpg=PA49&amp;dq=gothic+bible+oldest+germanic#v=onepage&amp;q=gothic%20bible%20oldest%20germanic&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Language History, Language Change and Language Relationship: an introduction to historical and comparative linguistics
             </i>
            </a>
            . Walter de Gruyter &amp; Co. p. 49.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/3-11-014784-X" title="Special:BookSources/3-11-014784-X">
             3-11-014784-X
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             The oldest extensive text is a Gothic Bible translation produced by the Gothic bishop Wulfilas (meaning 'Little Wolf') in the 4th century
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Language+History%2C+Language+Change+and+Language+Relationship%3A+an+introduction+to+historical+and+comparative+linguistics&amp;rft.pages=49&amp;rft.pub=Walter+de+Gruyter+%26+Co.&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=3-11-014784-X&amp;rft.aulast=Hock&amp;rft.aufirst=Hans+Heinrich&amp;rft.au=Joseph%2C+Brian+D.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DoGH-RCW1fzsC%26pg%3DPA49%26lpg%3DPA49%26dq%3Dgothic%2Bbible%2Boldest%2Bgermanic%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dgothic%2520bible%2520oldest%2520germanic%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-34">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-34">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.liternet.bg/publish10/eshopova/manastiryt.htm" rel="nofollow">
             "The monastery in the village of Zlatna Livada – the oldest in Europe"

            </q>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=ESSENTIAL+HISTORY+OF+BULGARIA+IN+SEVEN+PAGES&amp;rft.pages=2-3&amp;rft.pub=Bulgarian+Academy+of+Sciences&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.aulast=Ivanov&amp;rft.aufirst=Lyubomir&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fen.wikisource.org%2Fwiki%2FEssential_History_of_Bulgaria_in_Seven_Pages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
