           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Krum+%28Bulgar+khan%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F323896%2FKrum&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-42">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-42">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42725/The-spread-of-Christianity" rel="nofollow">
             "The Spread of Christianity"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              27 July
             </span>
             2014
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Although Boris's baptism was into the Eastern church, he subsequently wavered between Rome and Constantinople until the latter was persuaded to grant de facto autonomy to Bulgaria in church affairs.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=The+Spread+of+Christianity&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42725%2FThe-spread-of-Christianity&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-43">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-43">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Crampton, R.J. (2007).
            <i>
             Bulgaria
            </i>
            . Oxford University Press. p. 13.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954158-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954158-4">
             978-0-19-954158-4
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgaria&amp;rft.pages=13&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-954158-4&amp;rft.aulast=Crampton&amp;rft.aufirst=R.J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-EB-44">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-EB_44-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42725/The-spread-of-Christianity" rel="nofollow">
             "Reign of Simeon I"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              27 July
             </span>
             2014
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Bulgaria's conversion had a political dimension, for it contributed both to the growth of central authority and to the merging of Bulgars and Slavs into a unified Bulgarian people.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Reign+of+Simeon+I&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42725%2FThe-spread-of-Christianity&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-RCJ_BG-45">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-RCJ_BG_45-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Crampton, R.J. (2007).
            <i>
             Bulgaria
            </i>
            . Oxford University Press. p. 12.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954158-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-954158-4">
             978-0-19-954158-4
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             No single act did more, in the long run, to weld Christian Slav and Proto-Bulgar into a Bulgarian people than the conversion of 864.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgaria&amp;rft.pages=12&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-954158-4&amp;rft.aulast=Crampton&amp;rft.aufirst=R.J.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_First_Golden_Age-46">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_First_Golden_Age_46-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <a href="#CITEREFThe_First_Golden_Age">
            The First Golden Age
           </a>
           .
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Spread-47">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-Spread_47-0">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42725/The-spread-of-Christianity" rel="nofollow">
             "Reign of Simeon I"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              4 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Under Simeon's successors Bulgaria was beset by internal dissension provoked by the spread of Bogomilism (a dualist religious sect) and by assaults from Magyars, Pechenegs, the Rus, and Byzantines.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Reign+of+Simeon+I&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42725%2FThe-spread-of-Christianity&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

         <li id="cite_note-51">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Synopsis+Historiarum&amp;rft.pages=457&amp;rft.edition=Hans+Thurn&amp;rft.date=1973&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-11-002285-8&amp;rft.aulast=Scylitzae&amp;rft.aufirst=Ioannis&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-52">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-52">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            Pavlov, Plamen (2005).
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.liternet.bg/publish13/p_pavlov/buntari/zagovorite.htm" rel="nofollow">
             "The plots of 'master Presian the Bulgarian
             <span style="padding-right:0.2em;">
              '
             </span>
             "
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Rebels and adventurers in medieval Bulgaria
            </i>
            (in Bulgarian). LiterNet
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             And, in the Spring of 1018, "the party of capitulation" prevailed and Basil II freely entered the then capital of Bulgaria Ochrid.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Rebels+and+adventurers+in+medieval+Bulgaria&amp;rft.atitle=The+plots+of+%27master+Presian+the+Bulgarian%27&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.au=Pavlov%2C+Plamen&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.liternet.bg%2Fpublish13%2Fp_pavlov%2Fbuntari%2Fzagovorite.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Bulgaria+%E2%80%93+Second+Bulgarian+Empire&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42727%2FThe-second-Bulgarian-empire%3Fanchor%3Dref476458&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

         <li id="cite_note-EB1911-56">

              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a href="/wiki/James_David_Bourchier" title="James David Bourchier">
             James David Bourchier
            </a>
            (1911).
            <a class="external text" href="http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/1911_Encyclopædia_Britannica/Bulgaria/History">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+Bulgaria&amp;rft.pub=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica+1911&amp;rft.date=1911&amp;rft.au=James+David+Bourchier&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fen.wikisource.org%2Fwiki%2F1911_Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica%2FBulgaria%2FHistory&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-57">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-57">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Ivanov, Lyubomir (2007).
            <a class="external text" href="http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Essential_History_of_Bulgaria_in_Seven_Pages">
             <i>
              ESSENTIAL HISTORY OF BULGARIA IN SEVEN PAGES
             </i>
            </a>
            . Bulgarian Academy of Sciences. p. 4
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             The capital Tarnovo became a political, economic, cultural and religious centre seen as 'the third Rome' in contrast to Constantinople's decline after the Byzantine heartland in Asia Minor was lost to the Turks during the late 11th century.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=ESSENTIAL+HISTORY+OF+BULGARIA+IN+SEVEN+PAGES&amp;rft.pages=4&amp;rft.pub=Bulgarian+Academy+of+Sciences&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.aulast=Ivanov&amp;rft.aufirst=Lyubomir&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fen.wikisource.org%2Fwiki%2FEssential_History_of_Bulgaria_in_Seven_Pages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-58">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-58">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110916221127/http://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/Mongolia.html" rel="nofollow">
             "The Golden Horde"
            </a>
            . Library of Congress Mongolia country study. Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/Mongolia.html" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 16 September 2011
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              4 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             The Mongols maintained sovereignty over eastern Russia from 1240 to 1480, and they controlled the upper Volga area, the territories of the former Volga Bulghar state, Siberia, the northern Caucasus,
             <b>
              Bulgaria (for a time)
             </b>
             , the Crimea, and Khwarizm
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Golden+Horde&amp;rft.pub=Library+of+Congress+Mongolia+country+study&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.shsu.edu%2F~his_ncp%2FMongolia.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Ottoman_rule-59">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-Ottoman_rule_59-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Ottoman_rule_59-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Ottoman_rule_59-2">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               c
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42728/Ottoman-rule" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria – Ottoman rule"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              21 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             With the capture of a rump Bulgarian kingdom centred at Bdin (Vidin) in 1396, the last remnant of Bulgarian independence disappeared. ... The Bulgarian nobility was destroyed—its members either perished, fled, or accepted Islam and Turkicization—and the peasantry was enserfed to Turkish masters.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Bulgaria+%E2%80%93+Ottoman+rule&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42728%2FOttoman-rule&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Jireček-60">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Geschichte+der+Bulgaren&amp;rft.pub=Nachdr.+d.+Ausg.+Prag&amp;rft.date=1876&amp;rft.isbn=3-487-06408-1&amp;rft.aulast=Jire%C4%8Dek&amp;rft.aufirst=K.+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DVBhThVLpc4MC%26pg%3DPA88&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

         <li id="cite_note-61">

            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=zQsB_AghBKkC&amp;pg=PA8&amp;lpg=PA8&amp;dq=conversation+to+islam+to+the+balkans#v=onepage&amp;q=conclusion&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Conversion+to+Islam+in+the+Balkans%3A+Kisve+Bahas%C4%B1+%E2%80%93+Petitions+and+Ottoman+Social+Life%2C+1670%E2%80%931730&amp;rft.pages=193&amp;rft.pub=BRILL&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=90-04-13576-6&amp;rft.aulast=Minkov&amp;rft.aufirst=Anton&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DzQsB_AghBKkC%26pg%3DPA8%26lpg%3DPA8%26dq%3Dconversation%2Bto%2Bislam%2Bto%2Bthe%2Bbalkans%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dconclusion%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">

         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-62">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-62">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Detrez, Raymond (2008).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=htMUx8qlWCMC&amp;pg=PA47&amp;dq=millet++bulgarian+identity+detrez#v=onepage&amp;q=Smith%2C%20A.%20The%20Ethnic%20Origins%20of%20Nations.%20&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Europe and the Historical Legacies in the Balkans
             </i>
            </a>
            . Peter Lang Publishers. p. 36.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/90-5201-374-8" title="Special:BookSources/90-5201-374-8">
             90-5201-374-8
            </a>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Europe+and+the+Historical+Legacies+in+the+Balkans&amp;rft.pages=36&amp;rft.pub=Peter+Lang+Publishers&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=90-5201-374-8&amp;rft.aulast=Detrez&amp;rft.aufirst=Raymond&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DhtMUx8qlWCMC%26pg%3DPA47%26dq%3Dmillet%2B%2Bbulgarian%2Bidentity%2Bdetrez%23v%3Donepage%26q%3DSmith%252C%2520A.%2520The%2520Ethnic%2520Origins%2520of%2520Nations.%2520%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-63">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-63">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Fishman, Joshua A. (2010).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=7oAUeUVtc58C&amp;pg=PA276&amp;dq=there+were+almost+no+remnants+of+a+Bulgarian+ethnic+identity;#v=onepage&amp;q=there%20were%20almost%20no%20remnants%20of%20a%20Bulgarian%20ethnic%20identity%3B&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              "Handbook of Language and Ethnic Identity," Disciplinary and Regional Perspectives
             </i>
            </a>
            . Oxford University Press. p. 276.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-537492-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-19-537492-4">
             0-19-537492-4
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             There were almost no remnants of a Bulgarian ethnic identity; the population defined itself as Christians, according to the Ottoman system of millets, that is, communities of religious beliefs. The first attempts to define a Bulgarian ethnicity started at the beginning of the 19th century.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%22Handbook+of+Language+and+Ethnic+Identity%2C%22+Disciplinary+and+Regional+Perspectives&amp;rft.pages=276&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=0-19-537492-4&amp;rft.aulast=Fishman&amp;rft.aufirst=Joshua+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3D7oAUeUVtc58C%26pg%3DPA276%26dq%3Dthere%2Bwere%2Balmost%2Bno%2Bremnants%2Bof%2Ba%2BBulgarian%2Bethnic%2Bidentity%3B%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dthere%2520were%2520almost%2520no%2520remnants%2520of%2520a%2520Bulgarian%2520ethnic%2520identity%253B%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-64">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-64">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Roudometof, Victor; Robertson, Roland (2001).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=I9p_m7oXQ00C&amp;pg=PA68&amp;dq=rum+millet+identity#v=onepage&amp;q=rum%20millet%20identity&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Nationalism, globalization, and orthodoxy: the social origins of ethnic conflict in the Balkans
             </i>
            </a>
            . Greenwood Publishing Group. pp. 68–71.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-313-31949-9" title="Special:BookSources/0-313-31949-9">
             0-313-31949-9
            </a>
            .
           </cite>

           <cite class="citation book">
            Pinon, Rene (1913).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=xL9DAAAAYAAJ&amp;q=prusse+des+balkans&amp;dq=prusse+des+balkans" rel="nofollow">

              L'Europe et la Jeune Turquie: les aspects nouveaux de la question d'Orient

            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

             </span>

            </span>

            <q>
             On a dit souvent de la Bulgarie qu'elle est la Prusse des Balkans
            </q>
           </cite>

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=South-East+Europe+Review&amp;rft.atitle=External+Migration+in+Bulgaria&amp;rft.issue=3%2F99&amp;rft.pages=124&amp;rft.date=1999-10&amp;rft.aulast=Mintchev&amp;rft.aufirst=Vesselin&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ceeol.com%2Faspx%2Fgetdocument.aspx%3Flogid%3D5%26id%3D473FBAEF-623D-4ADA-903A-17241B78BDDB&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>

         <li id="cite_note-83">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-83">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Chenoweth, Erica (2010).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=JyD_AmGnu34C&amp;pg=PA129&amp;dq=bulgaria+refugees+economy#v=onepage&amp;q=bulgaria%20refugees%20economy&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Rethinking Violence: States and Non-State Actors in Conflict
             </i>
            </a>
            . Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs. p. 129.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-262-01420-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-262-01420-5">
             978-0-262-01420-5
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             Bulgaria, for example, had a net surplus of refugees and was faced with the daunting task of absorbing thousands of Bulgarian refugees from Greece over a relatively short period. While international loans from the Red Cross and other organizations helped to defray the substantial costs of accommodating surplus populations, it placed a strenuous financial burden on states that were still recovering from the war an experiencing economic downturn as well as political upheaval.
            </q>
           </cite>

          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Political_Atmosphere_in_the_1970s_96-0">
             ^
            </a>

            The Political Atmosphere in the 1970s
           </a>
           .
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-97">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-97">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation news">
            Bohlen, Celestine (17 October 1991).
            <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/17/world/bulgaria-vote-gives-key-role-to-ethnic-turks.html" rel="nofollow">
             "Vote Gives Key Role to Ethnic Turks"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">
              The New York Times
             </a>
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             in 1980s ... the Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, began a campaign of cultural assimilation that forced ethnic Turks to adopt Slavic names, closed their mosques and prayer houses and suppressed any attempts at protest. One result was the mass exodus of more than 300,000 ethnic Turks to neighboring Turkey in 1989
            </q>
           </cite>

         <li id="cite_note-192">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-192">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110710020431/http://www.usaid.gov/pubs/cbj2002/ee/bg/" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria Overview"
            </a>
            .
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USAID" title="USAID">
             USAID
            </a>
            . 2002. Archived from
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.usaid.gov/pubs/cbj2002/ee/bg/" rel="nofollow">
             the original
            </a>
            on 10 July 2011
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              2 November
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgaria+Overview&amp;rft.pub=USAID&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.usaid.gov%2Fpubs%2Fcbj2002%2Fee%2Fbg%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-193">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-193">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42756/Late-communist-rule" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria – Late Communist rule"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Bulgaria gave the highest priority to scientific and technological advancement and the development of trade skills appropriate to an industrial state. In 1948 approximately 80 percent of the population drew their living from the soil, but by 1988 less than one-fifth of the labour force was engaged in agriculture, with the rest concentrated in industry and the service sector.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Bulgaria+%E2%80%93+Late+Communist+rule&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42756%2FLate-communist-rule&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Economies-194">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-Economies_194-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Economies_194-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/een/005/article_4326_en.htm" rel="nofollow">
             "The economies of Bulgaria and Romania"
            </a>
            .
            <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">
             European Commission
            </a>
            . January 2007
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>

           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+economies+of+Bulgaria+and+Romania&amp;rft.pub=European+Commission&amp;rft.date=2007-01&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fec.europa.eu%2Feconomy_finance%2Feen%2F005%2Farticle_4326_en.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-195">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-195">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            <i>
             OECD Economic Surveys
            </i>
            .
            <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
             OECD
            </a>
            . 1999. p. 24.
            <q>
             The previous 1997 Economic Survey of Bulgaria documented how a combination of difficult initial conditions, delays in structural reforms, ... culminated in the economic crisis of 1996–97.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=OECD+Economic+Surveys&amp;rft.pages=24&amp;rft.pub=OECD&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

             ^

         <li id="cite_note-302">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-302">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/bg" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria – Profile"
            </a>
            . UNESCO World Heritage Centre
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              4 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgaria+%E2%80%93+Profile&amp;rft.pub=UNESCO+World+Heritage+Centre&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwhc.unesco.org%2Fen%2Fstatesparties%2Fbg&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-303">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-303">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            MacDermott, Mercia (1998).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=gh4IE6toGJMC&amp;pg=PA226&amp;dq=nestinarstvo#v=onepage&amp;q=nestinarstvo&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Bulgarian Folk Customs
             </i>
            </a>
            . Jessica Kingsley Publishers. p. 226.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-85302-485-6" title="Special:BookSources/1-85302-485-6">
             1-85302-485-6
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             While dancing round fires and jumping over fires forms part of many Slav customs, dancing
             <i>
              on
             </i>
             fire does not, and it is therefore likely that nestinarstvo was inherited by the Bulgarians from the Hellenized Thracians who inhabited the land before them.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgarian+Folk+Customs&amp;rft.pages=226&amp;rft.pub=Jessica+Kingsley+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=1-85302-485-6&amp;rft.aulast=MacDermott&amp;rft.aufirst=Mercia&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3Dgh4IE6toGJMC%26pg%3DPA226%26dq%3Dnestinarstvo%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dnestinarstvo%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-304">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-304">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/en/RL/00191" rel="nofollow">
             "Nestinarstvo, messages from the past: the Panagyr of Saints Constantine and Helena in the village of Bulgari"
            </a>
            . UNESCO
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">

             </span>

           </cite>

            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-305">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-305">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            MacDermott, Mercia (1998).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=gh4IE6toGJMC&amp;pg=PA32&amp;dq=bulgarian+traditions#v=onepage&amp;q=folklore&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Bulgarian folk customs
             </i>
            </a>

            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

            .
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgarian+folk+customs&amp;rft.pages=65-70&amp;rft.pub=Jessica+Kingsley+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=1-85302-485-6&amp;rft.aulast=MacDermott&amp;rft.aufirst=Mercia&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3Dgh4IE6toGJMC%26pg%3DPA32%26dq%3Dbulgarian%2Btraditions%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dfolklore%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Sofia+Echo&amp;rft.atitle=The+Martenitsa+Story&amp;rft.date=2008-02-29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsofiaecho.com%2F2008%2F02%2F29%2F653749_reading-room-the-martenitsa-story&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

         <li id="cite_note-308">

            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=MUVgsK_GfxYC&amp;pg=PA11&amp;dq=bulgaria+slavic+culture#v=onepage&amp;q=bulgaria%20slavic%20culture&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

              An Introduction to post-Communist Bulgaria: Political, economic and social transformation
             </i>
            </a>

            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7190-6094-X" title="Special:BookSources/0-7190-6094-X">

            <span class="reference-accessdate">

            <q>
             Thus, with its early emphasis on Christian Orthodox scholarship, Bulgaria became the first major centre of Slavic culture
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Introduction+to+post-Communist+Bulgaria%3A+Political%2C+economic+and+social+transformation&amp;rft.pages=11&amp;rft.pub=Manchester+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=0-7190-6094-X&amp;rft.aulast=Giatzidis&amp;rft.aufirst=Emil&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DMUVgsK_GfxYC%26pg%3DPA11%26dq%3Dbulgaria%2Bslavic%2Bculture%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dbulgaria%2520slavic%2520culture%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-309">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-309">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Riha, Thomas (1964).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=_Bkddxc600IC&amp;pg=PA214&amp;dq=bulgaria+slavic+culture#v=onepage&amp;q=bulgaria%20slavic%20culture&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Readings in Russian Civilization
             </i>
            </a>
            . University of Chicago press. p. 214.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-226-71853-0" title="Special:BookSources/0-226-71853-0">

            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">

            <q>
             And it was mainly from Bulgaria that a rich supply of literary monuments was transferred to Kiev and other centres.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Readings+in+Russian+Civilization&amp;rft.pages=214&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Chicago+press&amp;rft.date=1964&amp;rft.isbn=0-226-71853-0&amp;rft.aulast=Riha&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3D_Bkddxc600IC%26pg%3DPA214%26dq%3Dbulgaria%2Bslavic%2Bculture%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dbulgaria%2520slavic%2520culture%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-310">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-310">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            McNeill, William Hardy (1963).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=_RsPrzrsAvoC&amp;pg=PA449&amp;dq=bulgaria+slavic+culture#v=onepage&amp;q=bulgaria%20slavic%20culture&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              The Rise of the West
             </i>
            </a>
            . The University of Chicago Press. p. 49.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-226-56141-0" title="Special:BookSources/0-226-56141-0">
             0-226-56141-0
            </a>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Accordingly, when Bulgaria was converted to Christianity (after 865), bringing massive Slavic-speaking populations within the pale of Christendom, a new literary language, Old Church Slavonic, directly based upon Bulgarian speech, developed for their use.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Rise+of+the+West&amp;rft.pages=49&amp;rft.pub=The+University+of+Chicago+Press&amp;rft.date=1963&amp;rft.isbn=0-226-56141-0&amp;rft.aulast=McNeill&amp;rft.aufirst=William+Hardy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3D_RsPrzrsAvoC%26pg%3DPA449%26dq%3Dbulgaria%2Bslavic%2Bculture%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dbulgaria%2520slavic%2520culture%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-311">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-311">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Ertl, Alan W (2008).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=X9PGRaZt-zcC&amp;pg=PA436&amp;dq=preslav+school+cyrillic#v=onepage&amp;q=preslav%20school%20cyrillic&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Toward understanding Europe: A political précis of continental integration
             </i>
            </a>
            . Universal Publishers, Inc. p. 436.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-59942-983-7" title="Special:BookSources/1-59942-983-7">
             1-59942-983-7

            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             At the beginning of the 10th century a new alphabet – the Cyrillic alphabet – was developed on the basis of Greek and Glagolitic cursive at the Preslav Literary School.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Toward+understanding+Europe%3A+A+political+pr%C3%A9cis+of+continental+integration&amp;rft.pages=436&amp;rft.pub=Universal+Publishers%2C+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=1-59942-983-7&amp;rft.aulast=Ertl&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan+W&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DX9PGRaZt-zcC%26pg%3DPA436%26dq%3Dpreslav%2Bschool%2Bcyrillic%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dpreslav%2520school%2520cyrillic%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-Cultural_life-312">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           ^
           <a href="#cite_ref-Cultural_life_312-0">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Cultural_life_312-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42715/The-arts" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria – The arts"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            . 2011
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             The early impetus of Bulgarian traditions in the arts was cut short by the Ottoman occupation in the 14th century, and many early masterpieces were destroyed. ... the foundations were laid for later artists such as Vladimir Dimitrov, an extremely gifted painter specializing in the rural scenes of his native country ... At the beginning of the 21st century, the best-known contemporary Bulgarian artist was Christo, an environmental sculptor known for wrapping famous structures
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Bulgaria+%E2%80%93+The+arts&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42715%2FThe-arts&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-313">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-313">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42715/The-arts" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria – The arts"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            . 2011
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             World classics and modern foreign dramas are typically produced, as well as both modern and traditional Bulgarian plays, including those by Ivan Vazov and poet Peyo Yavorov ... These included poets such as Pencho Slaveykov, Yavorov, and Dimcho Debelyanov ... More recent authors of note include poet Atanas Slavov, Yordan Radichkov, and Blaga Dimitrova.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Bulgaria+%E2%80%93+The+arts&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42715%2FThe-arts&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

         <li id="cite_note-litenc-315">

             ^

           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Literary+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.atitle=Elias+Canetti&amp;rft.date=2004-04-17&amp;rft.issn=1747-678X&amp;rft.aulast=Lorenz&amp;rft.aufirst=Dagmar+C.+G.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.litencyc.com%2Fphp%2Fspeople.php%3Frec%3Dtrue%26UID%3D725&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>

         <li id="cite_note-316">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-316">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Kremenliev, Boris A. (1952).
            <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=wOOfVFJWMLIC&amp;pg=PA52&amp;dq=bulgarian+music#v=onepage&amp;q=bulgarian%20music&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">
             <i>
              Bulgarian-Macedonian Folk Music
             </i>
            </a>
            . University of California Press. p. 52
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Bulgaria's scales are numerous, and it may be demonstrated that they are a fusion of Eastern and Western influences. ... first, Oriental scales; second, church modes: the osmoglasie ... third, the conventional scales of Western Europe. ... Among the scales which have comes to the Balkans from Asia, the pentatonic is one of the most widely used in Bulgaria. Whether it came from China or Japan, as Dobri Hristov suggests
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Bulgarian-Macedonian+Folk+Music&amp;rft.pages=52&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press&amp;rft.date=1952&amp;rft.aulast=Kremenliev&amp;rft.aufirst=Boris+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DwOOfVFJWMLIC%26pg%3DPA52%26dq%3Dbulgarian%2Bmusic%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dbulgarian%2520music%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-317">

         <li id="cite_note-318">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-318">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Lang, David Marshall (1976).
            <i>
             The Bulgarians: from pagan times to the Ottoman conquest
            </i>
            . Westview Press. p. 145.
            <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
             ISBN
            </a>
            <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-89158-530-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-89158-530-5">
             978-0-89158-530-5
            </a>
            .
            <q>
             John Kukuzel, the eminent Bulgarian/born reformer of Byzantine music.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Bulgarians%3A+from+pagan+times+to+the+Ottoman+conquest&amp;rft.pages=145&amp;rft.pub=Westview+Press&amp;rft.date=1976&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-89158-530-5&amp;rft.aulast=Lang&amp;rft.aufirst=David+Marshall&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">

          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation book">
            Grabar, André (1928).
            <i>
             La peinture religiouse en Bulgarie
            </i>
            . P. Geuthner. p. 95.
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=La+peinture+religiouse+en+Bulgarie&amp;rft.pages=95&amp;rft.pub=P.+Geuthner&amp;rft.date=1928&amp;rft.aulast=Grabar&amp;rft.aufirst=Andr%C3%A9&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
           ASIN: B005ZI4OV8
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-325">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-325">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/bulgaria" rel="nofollow">
             "Media Landscape – Bulgaria"
            </a>
            . European Journalism Centreaccessdate=2 May 2014.
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Media+Landscape+%E2%80%93+Bulgaria&amp;rft.pub=European+Journalism+Centreaccessdate%3D2+May+2014&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fejc.net%2Fmedia_landscapes%2Fbulgaria&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-326">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-326">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a href="/wiki/Federal_Research_Division" title="Federal Research Division">
             Library of Congress – Federal Research Division
            </a>
            (October 2006).
            <a class="external text" href="http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Bulgaria.pdf" rel="nofollow">
             "Country Profile: Bulgaria"
            </a>
            <span style="font-size:85%;">
             (PDF)
            </span>
            . Library of Congress. pp. 18,
            <b>
             23
            </b>
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              4 September
             </span>
             2009
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             Mass Media: In 2006 Bulgaria's print and broadcast media generally were considered unbiased, although the government dominated broadcasting through the state-owned Bulgarian National Television (BNT) and Bulgarian National Radio (BNR) and print news dissemination through the largest press agency, the Bulgarian Telegraph Agency. [...]Human Rights: In the early 2000s, Bulgaria generally has been rated highly on the issue of human rights. However, some exceptions exist. Although the media have a record of unbiased reporting, Bulgaria's lack of specific legislation protecting the media from state interference is a theoretical weakness.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Country+Profile%3A+Bulgaria&amp;rft.pages=18%2C+%27%27%2723%27%27%27&amp;rft.pub=Library+of+Congress&amp;rft.date=2006-10&amp;rft.au=Library+of+Congress+%E2%80%93+Federal+Research+Division&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Flcweb2.loc.gov%2Ffrd%2Fcs%2Fprofiles%2FBulgaria.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

             <i>
              <b>
               a
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Sport_335-1">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               b
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Sport_335-2">
            <sup>
             <i>
              <b>
               c
              </b>
             </i>
            </sup>
           </a>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           <cite class="citation web">
            <a class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42718/Sport-and-recreation" rel="nofollow">
             "Bulgaria- Sport and recreation"
            </a>
            .
            <i>
             Encyclopædia Britannica
            </i>
            . 2011
            <span class="reference-accessdate">
             . Retrieved
             <span class="nowrap">
              20 December
             </span>
             2011
            </span>
            .
            <q>
             In international sports competition, Bulgarians have excelled in tennis, wrestling, boxing, and gymnastics, but the country's greatest repute may be in weight-lifting. ... Fans of football (soccer), the most popular sport in Bulgaria, were buoyed by the success of the national team in the 1994 World Cup, when it advanced to the semi-final match under the leadership of forward Hristo Stoichkov. The premier league in Bulgaria has 16 teams, of which four play in Sofia: CSKA, Levski, Slavia, and Lokomotiv.
            </q>
           </cite>
           <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Bulgaria-+Sport+and+recreation&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F84090%2FBulgaria%2F42718%2FSport-and-recreation&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABulgaria">
            <span style="display:none;">
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </li>

          <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/Special:Search/Bulgaria" title="v:Special:Search/Bulgaria">
           Learning resources
          </a>
          from Wikiversity
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
               <div>
                <div class="plainlist">
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    1
                   </sup>
                   <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">
                    Oceanic islands
                   </a>
                   within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <sup>
                    2
                   </sup>
                   Some countries completely outside the conventional geographical boundaries of Europe are commonly associated with the continent due to ethnological links.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                </div>
               </div>
              </td>

       <ul style="margin:0.1em 0 0">
        <li style="display:inline">
         <span style="display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap">
          <span style="margin:0 0.5em">
           <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Bulgaria.svg">
